🫒🫦🫒 Fried Olive Cream-Cheese Bites… because snacks (you) deserve scrumptious snacks

These are inspired by the iconic Trader Joe’s Fried Olive Bites that *barely* hit shelves every holiday szn, but with a Maghrebi twist- because who wouldn’t want harissa, tahini, or Moroccan spices at their holiday table? 🤲🏻

They’re super simple to make & easy to prep beforehand (just freeze the stuffed olives sans breading & prepare to fry the day of the party (read: throwing ass).🍑

Here’s how to make them:
* 10-12 ounce pitted, Castelvetrano Olives
* 1/2 cup panko bread crumbs, or almond meal
* 2 tbsp nutritional yeast
* 1 tbsp sumac
* 1 tsp coriander
* 2 tbsp nutritional yeast
* 1/2 tsp fine kosher salt
* 2 eggs, beaten
* neutral-high smoke point oil, for frying
{Cream Cheese Filling}
* 1/3 cup cream cheese, softened
* 2 tbsp sugar
* 1/2 tbsp sumac
* 1/2 tsp ras el hanout
* pinch of sea salt
{Harissa Maple Dipping Sauce}
* 2 tbsp vegan yogurt
* 1 tbsp tahini
* 1 tbsp maple syrup
* 1 tbsp harissa
* 1/4 tsp garlic powder
* pinch of cumin
* salt, to taste
Process
1. Add the cream cheese, ras el hanout, & sumac to a bowl. Using a hand-held blender, whip the ingredients until incorporated. Place into a piping or Ziploc bag to fill the pitted olives. Set aside.
2. Make your breadcrumb mixture by whisking together panko, nutritional yeast, sumac, & salt until combined. Beat your eggs in a separate bowl. Set aside.
3. Remove olives from the jar & pat dry.
4. Fill each olive fully with the filling using a piping bag or Ziploc bag (with a TINY hole cut from the corner).
5. Coat olive in beaten egg, then the breadcrumbs. Repeat once more. I like to freeze the olive for 15 to 20 minutes before frying.
6. Heat a small saucepan with high smoke point oil over medium heat. The oil is ready to fry when you drop a breadcrumb into the pot & it sizzles. Fry 2 to 3 olives at a time. Dry on a paper-lined plate.
7. Make the dipping sauce by blending all of the ingredients until combined. Taste & adjust seasoning to taste.
8. Serve in a cocktail glass w/ fresh sprigs of rosemary cause you’re fun & dive in!

#olives #partysnacks #vegansnacks #easyrecipes #traderjoesrecipes #traderjoesfinds

🇵🇷❄️🥧Coconut CAN be festive!! Holly jolly isn’t all chocolate cookies and fruitcake. Coquito Pie is how you can also tis the season #IKEAPartner

This pie is inspired by coquito, a traditional holiday cocktail from Puerto Rico that’s creamy, coconutty, and bound to put you and your family on your 🍑

Not only is it decadent, but it’s perfectly spiced, sexy, and scrumptious- like my favorite “VINTERSAGA” Ginger Thins from @ikeausa (along with their adorably festive & affordable holiday decor to DECK THESE STREETS) 🫡🎄🕎 

Each bite reminds me of December nights making batches of this drink with my mom as gifts for my teachers, family, and my childhood bestie Sydni who went feral for a glass 😭

Here’s how to make it:
Crust
-2 cups “VINTERSAGA” ginger crumbs 
-2 tbsp brown sugar
-1 tbsp white miso
-1 tsp cinnamon
-1/2 tsp ginger
-1/4 tsp nutmeg
-1/3 cup butter, melted
Coconut Filling
- (1) 15 oz can of FULL FAT coconut milk
- 3 tbsp cornstarch
-1/2 cup sugar
-1/4 tsp cinnamon
-1/2 tsp kosher salt
-1/4 tsp nutmeg, more to taste
-1/2 tsp rum extract
-1/2 tsp coconut extract

Process:
1. Preheat oven to 350F. In a food processor, blend ginger thins, cinnamon, ginger, and nutmeg until a fine crumb. Add brown sugar, miso, and butter and pulse until it forms a sort of dough. Press into a 9” pie pan, pierce the bottom of the pan with a fork and bake for 8 to 10 mins. Let cool
2. In a saucepan, whisk together the cornstarch, sugar, and spices until combined. Slowly whisk in about 1/4 of the coconut milk into the pan and stir until incorporated with no lumps of cornstarch remaining. Add the remaining coconut milk.
3. Cook over medium heat until bubbling, whisking consistently. Reduce heat to low and cook for 5 mins. Use a rubber spatula to scrape the sides. Once “jiggly”, remove from heat and whisk in the extracts. Let cool for 10 mins.
4. Once cool, pour into pie crust. Cover with plastic wrap, ensuring it touches the surface of the coconut filling so no film forms. Refrigerate overnight.
5. Garnish w/ whipped topping, toasted coconut flakes, a dusting of cinnamon

#coquito #pie #veganbaking

🥕🧑🏽‍🌾MAPLE-HARISSA GLAZED CARROT PASTRY...This is a snacker’s world and we live in it, THANKFULLY! 🫵🏽

When shit hits the fan and you’re frozen, turn to (making) a snack and SZA’s new album- both are guaranteed to leave you with a feeling of belonging and comfort. 🫠

This puff pastry is my favorite way to use up a bundle of carrots. Perfect for a party, excellent for yourself, will be devoured in an instant. 🧍🏽

Here’s how to make it:
- 1 lb rainbow carrots(about 8-10 medium to large carrots)
- 2 tablespoons harissa paste
- 1/4 cup maple syrup
- 3 tablespoons olive oil
- 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon & coriander
- 1/4 teaspoon cumin
- 2 rosemary stems
- 1/2 tsp salt
- 1 store-bought puff pastry
- 6oz ricotta
- 2oz goat cheese
- 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
- 1 tbsp sugar
- pinch of salt

Process
1. Preheat oven to 400F. Rinse carrots, reserve carrot stems, and slice carrots in 1/2 lengthwise. 
2. In a bowl, whisk harissa, maple syrup, olive oil, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, and salt until combined. Taste and adjust seasoning. Reserve 1/4 cup of glaze. Toss the remaining glaze w/ carrots on a sheet tray. Roast for 20 to 25 minutes.
3. While carrots roast, whip together ricotta, goat cheese, sugar, vanilla, and salt until combined. Place puff pastry on a 9x12 sheet tray. Score a 1” border around the puff pastry lightly. Generously pierce the inner section with a fork to reduce how much it puffs up. Bake for 15 mins with carrots until lightly golden. Remove and let cool
4. Spread ricotta on the puff pastry within the border. Layer carrots on top organically or in a pattern. Bake for an additional 5 mins until the crust is golden. Remove and let cool
5. In a small saucepan, add rosemary stems and reserved glaze. Stir over medium-low heat until fragrant and the glaze coats the back of a spoon. Brush onto carrots on the tart. 
6. Garnish w/ herbs or crispy carrot top stems (fried in olive oil for 30 seconds) and flaky salt.
7. Dive in

#partyfood #vegetarianrecipes #carrots #puffpastry #snackideas #appetizers #harissa

☕️🍸Yemeni Spiced Espresso Martini’s are as important as the vibes you serve it with (or in) 🫡 #UOpartner

 I’ve been preparing for holiday party szn with @urbanoutfitters, my fav for all things cutie glassware, holiday decor, and ambiance. #UOCommunity #CelebrateWithUO @urbanoutfitters

🇾🇪 Yemen has played such an VITAL role for the coffee world, cultivating its crop for CENTURIES so we could all indulge. This twist on an espresso martini is inspired by the flair, flavor, and icon behavior that is a Yemeni latte: spiced with ginger, clove, cinnamon, and cardamom.

Here’s how to make it:
* 1 to 2 ounces vodka or non-alcoholic spirit of choice
* 1 ounce espresso, chilled (1 tsp matcha + 1/4 cup hot water)
* Dash of cardamom and flaky salt(less than 1/8 tsp)
* 1/8 tsp cinnamon & ginger
* 1-ounce non-dairy milk of choice
* 1-ounce almond liqueur or khalua (substitute with orgeat for a mocktail)
Process
1. Add spices to bottom of cup where espresso will be pulled into. Make 1 shot of espresso and chill in the freezer for about 10 minutes.
2. Add the vodka, chilled espresso, almond liqueur, milk, and flaky salt in a shaker with ice. Shake for 1 to 2 minutes until frothy.
3. Using the strainer, strain the mixture into a chilled glass. Garnish with flaky salt and cinnamon and 3 cardamom pods.

#espressomartini #cocktails #partyrecipes #fundrinks #plantbasedrecipes

🧍🏽Mushroom stew! When plans are canceled, remember that you deserve a meal as scrumptious as you are

This rich, cozy, silky mushroom stew is inspired by the iconic Mushroom French Dip sandwich from @eszettla (with some North African flair and spice)

Here’s how to make it:
Cauliflower Mash:
1 head of cauliflower
8 cups water
3 tbsp miso
1 tsp salt
2 tbsp butter
1 garlic clove, minced
2 tbsp cooking liquid 

Mushroom Stew 
8 oz mixed mushrooms
1 yellow onion
2 tbsp butter
Pinch of salt
1/2 tsp cinnamon
1/2 tsp chilli powder
1/2 tsp ginger
1 tbsp preserved lemon paste (sub w/ juice of 1 lemon
2 tbsp chopped tarragon
Slurry: 1 1/2 cup water + 2 tbsp flour

Process:
1. Remove cauliflower from stems into florets. Add to a pot of water (8 cups + miso) and bring to a boil over medium high heat. Reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook for 20-25 minutes.
2. Reserve 1/4 cup cooking liquid, then strain. Add to a food processor w/ butter, garlic, and cumin. Puree until smooth. Add cooking liquid 2 tbsp at a time if needed. Set aside
3. In a skillet, melt 2 tbsp butter over medium heat. Add onions and sautéed for 6 to 8 mins until slightly golden. Add additional 2 tbsp butter and sauté spices and garlic until fragrant. 
4. Add mushrooms w/ splash of water. Season w/ a pinch of salt, cover and cook for 5 to 7 minutes. Stir consistently.
5. Once mushrooms have cooked down, add preserved lemon paste and tarragon. Toss to coat. Pour in slurry and stir until sauce thickens and is combined. 
6. Serve over cauliflower mash w/ fresh parm and herbs.

#mushrooms #cauliflower #veganrecipes #holidayrecipes #veganholidays #comfortfood

🤲🏻Making brownies from scratch gives major pick-me-choose-me vibes, and as someone who’s tried, elevating boxed brownies is 10x better

Brownies are the only form of chocolate I will put in me… and only if they’re made this way. 🍫🫦🍫

First step: get boxed brownie mix, I love @simplemills ’ Almond Flour Boxed Brownie Mix because they’re Gluten-Free and made with the best of the best ingredients that make me feel 10/10. #simplemillspartner

The next three steps are below, have fun and take the easy route:
Step 1: Add browned butter to your mix in place of melted butter. Brown butter by melting a stick of butter over medium-low heat, swirling consistently until the milk solids turn to an amber color
Step 2: TAHINI-ALMOND SWIRL: Swirl in a nut/seed butter into the batter.
-2 tbsp tahini (seed butter)
-2  tbsp confectioners’ sugar
-1 tbsp oat milk
-1/2 tsp almond extract
-pinch of fine kosher salt
*Dollop the tahini mixture in 4 to 5 areas. Using a skewer, carefully swirl the mixture into the batter. 
Step 3: Use a different shaped pan to change the dining experience. A tart pan will give a fluted rim as extra and spectacular as you are.
Step 4: HAVE FUN and take it easy

#brownies #brownielovers #bakinghacks #easyveganrecipes #bakingtips #tahini

Snickerdoodles are the BEST cookies… as much as the holidays having their UPS AND DOWNS 🤲🏻

These fluffy, tangy, sugar coated cookies are a staple in my house. It has been since the first school holiday gift catalog in elementary school that left my brother and I eating our weight in cookie dough over xmas break 🫄🏻

They’re easy, come together in an hour (with little chill time) and have a floral effervescence that mellows out any angst 🫶🏼

Here’s how to make them:
 * 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
* 1 tsp ground cardamom
* 3/4 tsp cream of tartar
* 1/2 tsp cornstarch
* 1/4 tsp baking soda
* 1/4 tsp fine salt
* 1/4 tsp ground cinnamon
* 1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened
* 3/4 cup granulated sugar
* 1 tbsp ground flaxseed meal w/ 3 tablespoons water, sub w/ 1 large egg
* 1 tbsp orange blossom water
For the coating
* 2 tbsp granulated sugar
* 1 tsp ground cinnamon
* 1/4 tsp ground cardamom
* Flaky sea salt, for sprinkling (optional)

Process:
1.In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cardamom, cream of tartar, cornstarch, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon until well combined

2.In another bowl, beat the butter and sugar until light and fluffy, about 2-3 mins. Add flax egg and orange blossom water and beat until combined. 

3.Add half of the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until incorporated. Add the other half (don’t overmix the dough). Cover with plastic wrap and freeze for 30 to 45 mins or chill in the refrigerator overnight (if you have the patience)

4. While dough chills, preheat oven to 350F and position a rack in the middle of the oven. Make the coating by stirring together sugar, cinnamon, and cardamom.
5. Using a tbsp or small ice cream scooper, scoop out heaping tbsp (about 1 1/2 tbsp) of the dough. Form into a ball and coat in cinnamon-cardamom sugar. Place on a non-stick baking tray 2 inches apart.
6. Bake one sheet at a time for 9 to 11 minutes, rotating trays halfway through bake time. Remove and bang tray on counter to create more of a crackly top. Garnish w/ flaky salt.
7. Let cool on baking sheet for 10 mins. Then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. 
#snickerdoodle #holidaybaking #christmascookies #veganbakingrecipes

Coquito (Coconut C0cktail) would put you on your as$, respectfully 🫶🏼🇵🇷🥥😋 (RECIPE BELOW)

This creamy, coconut drink is a Puerto Rican tradition that just keeps giving. Served throughout the holidays and especially during new year festivities, each sip is like a hug on your tongue and a kick in your throat 🤪

This dairy free version came with a lot of skepticism when I first made it for my family, but it’s now the only way we make it. Just as tasty as the original to the point where it was gifted to all my high school professors (and the principal) every year for the holidays. 

And yuh, besties and I did sneak some into the cafeteria 😌

Here’s how to make it:
*(1) 15-ounce can of “Coco Lopez” cream of coconut 
(1) 8-ounce can of sweetened coconut condensed milk 
2 cups oat or coconut milk
1 cup of white rum
1 shot (2 tablespoons) 151 rum, optional but be cautious as this rum is dangerous if too much is added
1/2 teaspoon cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg
pinch of sea salt

DIRECTIONS
1.To a blender, add all of the ingredients.
2.Blend until combined and smooth.
3.Taste the mixture and adjust flavors/seasoning per personal preference.
**Too strong? Add more oat milk (about 1/2 cup at a time)
**Lacking flavor and ✨spice ✨? Add a pinch more of cinnamon and nutmeg

#coquito #puertoricanfood #puertorico🇵🇷 #drinks #newyearsfood #partydrinks #vegandrinks #coconut

Eternally grateful for this year and every soul I’ve connected with, opportunity floated my way, and magnesium gummy devoured to calm all angst ♥️ Thank you for being on this journey with me. There’s no rush, there’s no timeline; take it easy on yourself.

🍲🇲🇦I could eat (devour) this (harira) every single day (for eternity) RECIPE BELOW ⬇️ 

This tomato-legume based soup from Morocco is a staple. The creme de la creme. The apple to your bottom jeans. 

Although this isn’t traditional, it’s my version of a soup (that kickstarts the meal of so many families) using ingredients that I have access to and that make me feel nourished. 
Every sip reminds me of my grandmother who would come to the states for 6 months at a time, and every evening she’d make this for my mother because it was simply THAT GOOD.

Filling. PACKED full of flavor. Simple. Good food doesn’t have to be time-consuming, but it should cover all bases (nutritionally, spiritually, and orgasmically). Harira is a home run. ⚾️ 

Here’s how to make it:
{Tomato slurry}
* 1 (14oz) can diced tomatoes
* 1/2 large white onion, diced
{Soup}
* 2 tbsp olive oil
* “tomato slurry”
* 1 can of chickpeas or white beans ( juice included)
* 2 tbsp cilantro, chopped
* 2 tbsp parsley, chopped
* 2 cups of water
* 1/2 tbsp sea salt
* 1 tsp pepper
* 1/2 tsp cinnamon
* 1 tsp ground ginger
* 1/4 tsp turmeric
* 1/2 tsp saffron 
* 1 cup dry red lentils, rinsed
* 2 tbsp tomato paste mixed with 2  cups of water
*4oz vermicelli noodles, broken into 3inch pieces
* flour slurry (1/4 cup of flour mixed with 1 cup water)
* Juice of 1 lemon

1. In a food processor,  puree the tomatoes and white onion until a slurry consistency comes to fruition; set aside
2. Heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add your spices and toast them for about 30 seconds.
3.  Stir in the tomato slurry, chickpeas, dry lentils, cilantro, parsley, salt, and 2 cups of water; let simmer for 20 mins or until the lentils are cooked through. Stir every 5 minutes.
4. “Bloom” saffron threads in 1/2 cup of hot water.
5. Stir in the vermicelli, tomato paste mixture and saffron water; let simmer for 5 minutes.
6. Stir in flour slurry to thicken the soup. Add lemon juice. Taste and adjust seasoning.
7. Serve with spicy harissa, fresh lemon, and cracked pepper
8. Dive in!

#soupseason #comfortfood #healthydinner #veganrecipes #veganuary #moroccanfood #harira #souprecipes

Mushy food as your personality 🤭♥️ Assida (Moroccan/North African porridge) is guaranteed to be a staple 🇲🇦

Assida is a semolina porridge (originating from North Africa) that comes together in 5 minutes and is as versatile as the entire bushwhick community. Sweet, savory, or both- your call. Just make sure a drizzle of honey and slabs of butter are included on top. 🫡🤨

Here’s how to make it <3
Serves 2
Assida
- 100 grams coarse semolina (about 1/2 cup)
- 2 cups water
- 1/2 tsp salt
- 1 tablespoon butter
- 1/2 cup milk (not traditional but I prefer to add some)
Sautéed Peppers
- 3 peppers (green, yellow, red), thinly sliced
- 1 packet of sazon
- 2 garlic cloves, minced
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- Salt/pepper to taste
Seared Mushrooms
- 4 oz mushrooms of choice
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- Pinch of salt and pepper
Directions:
1. Prepare the sautéed peppers: In a cast iron, add the olive oil over medium heat. Add the sliced peppers with salt and toss to coat. Cover and cook for 5 minutes. Remove lid and add minced garlic and sazon. Continue stirring until wilted and slightly charred. Remove from heat.
2. Prepare Seared mushrooms: In same pan, heat the oil. Add the mushrooms and season with salt/pepper. Toss and cook for 3 to 4 minutes until golden. Remove.
3. Prepare assida: Bring a pot of 2 cups water to boil. Add the butter and salt, and stir until melted. Pour in the semolina and remove from heat. Continue stirring consistently until it thickens. Stir in milk (1/4 cup at a time) until a consistency similar to grits comes to fruition. Add more milk if needed. 
4. Plate aside in a bowl. Serve with a drizzle of honey. Garnish w/ sautéed peppers and mushrooms, a fried egg, and fresh parsley.

#porridge #healthybreakfast #easybreakfast #moroccanfood #assida #plantbasedrecipes #easybreakfastideas

🫰🏼🌞Coconut Turmeric Stew, cause I’m just trying to give parsnips some RESPECT. RECIPE BELOW ⬇️ *Siri play “RESPECT” by Aretha Franklin* 

This Coconut Turmeric Stew has QUICKLY become my favorite weekend meal to make for the week ahead. And by the week ahead I mean 2 to 3 days because you should stop eating day-old food. 🫡

It’s the kind of meal that gives you an out to bail on any plans you made when you maxed out your social calendar (and will). 🧍🏽

Here’s how to make it:
* 2 large parsnips, peeled and sliced diagonally
* 1/2 yellow onion, diced
* 4 to 5 garlic cloves, minced
* 1 1/2 inches of ginger, minced
* 2 tablespoons olive oil
* 1 tsp turmeric
* 1/2 tsp green cardamom powder (about 3 to 4 green cardamom pods)
* 1/4 tsp chili powder, add additional for more heat
* 1/2 tsp kosher salt, add more to taste
* 1/2 tsp black pepper
* 1 (15-ounce) can of full-fat coconut milk
* 2 cups water
* 2 tablespoons maple syrup
* zest of 2 limes
* 8-ounces tempeh or protein of choice (shrimp works wonderfully)
* white rice or grain of choice, to serve
* chives or cilantro, to garnish
* lime wedges, to garnish
* sumac, to garnish
Process:
1. Peel your parsnips, slice into 1/2-inch diagonal pieces. Dice your onion, and mince your garlic and ginger. Set aside.
2. If using tempeh, slice into cubes or diagonally (my preferred cut). Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a cast iron over med-heat and sear the tempeh on both sides. Remove from pan.
3. In same pan, add 2 tbsp olive oil. Saute onions for 3-4 minutes. Once translucent, add the ginger and garlic. Saute until fragrant, about 1-2 minutes.
4. Add spices to the pan and saute until fragrant, about 30 secs. Pour in the coconut milk. Fill the can with water and add it to the pan. Season with salt/ pepper. Stir in the lime zest and maple syrup.
5.  Add parsnips and tempeh, cover & let simmer for 15 minutes over medium-low heat (If using protein like chicken, simmer for 20 minutes; for shrimp, simmer for the last 5 minutes)
6. Taste and adjust seasoning. Serve over rice. garnish with chives or cilantro, lime wedges, and sumac.

#veganuary #stew #stews #comfortfood #parsnips #easydinners #plantbaseddinner

The tunacado is fine, but it’s 10x better as a Melt 🐟🤝 Recipe Below

Apparently, the tunacado is ALL THE RAGE. And it’s fine! It’s a sandwich. 

However, I think it would be ten times better as a melt. Enter the tunacado melt but with some Middle Eastern-North African flair manifested through harissa tuna salad.

Here’s how to make it:
{Harissa Tuna Salad}
* 1 can of skipjack tuna , liquid drained
* 2 tablespoons harissa paste, substitute sriracha 
* 1 tablespoon greek yogurt of choice (I used cashew)
* 1/4 teaspoon each: cumin and garlic powder
* zest of 1 lemon
* 2 tablespoons chopped dill
* pinch of sea salt and pepper, to taste
{Assembly}
* (2) slices of sourdough bread or bread of choice
* 1 tablespoon softened butter, split evenly
* 1/2 avocado, thinly sliced
* 2 ounces of mozzarella or American cheese, sliced
* coconut oil, to sear/toast

{Harissa Tuna Salad}
1. To a bowl, add the tuna, harissa (or sriracha), yogurt, spices, lemon zest, chopped dill, and salt. Stir together until incorporated. Set aside. 
{To assemble}
1. Slater the softened butter on one side of each piece of bread. Flip and prepare the sandwich on the non-buttered side.
2. Layer the thinly sliced cheese. Add the tuna salad (about 3/4 of the batch will fit). Layer thinly sliced avo on top!
3. Place the other piece of bread on top.
4. Heat an oiled skillet over medium-low heat. Add the sandwich and press down one side using a spatula or grill press. 
5. Add a splash of water around the side of the pan and cover the skillet. This will trap steam and allow the cheese to thoroughly melt in the center of the sandwich. Cook on both sides for about 2-3 minutes.
6. Once golden brown and the cheese is visibly melted, remove from heat. Slice in half and serve with pickles (this is non-negotiable).
7. Dive in!

#tunacado #sandwiches #easylunchideas #tunamelt

🤝EP 2// Produce Chronicles: Artichoke Miso Risotto- for when mercury retrograde ends and everything is your fault again! 🧍🏽(RECIPE BELOW ⬇️)

This recipe highlights the power that canned veggies have. Not only are they a more affordable, accessible, and shelf-stable version of produce- they bring with them a certain “je ne sais quoi” (read: salinity) that is perfect for stewed and simmered dishes... like RISOTTO!

Here’s how to make it:
-1 (15oz) can of artichoke hearts
-1 tsp sumac
-1/2 tsp ground allspice
-4 tbsp butter
-1/2 yellow onion, diced
-4 garlic cloves, minced
-2 tbsp preserved lemon paste, sub w/ lemon juice 
-1 cup arborio rice
-4 tbsp miso paste diluted in 4 cups water 
-1 sprig fresh rosemary or 1/4 teaspoon dried rosemary
-1 (15oz) can of great northern or cannellini beans
-1 oz (about 2-3 tbsp) grated parmigiano reggiano
-salt/pepper to taste

Process:

1. Drain artichokes. Heat 2 tbsp butter in a skillet over med heat. Add artichokes, stirring frequently until slightly charred. Add sumac and allspice, sauté until coated and fragrant. Remove from pan.
2. Make miso broth by whisking together miso paste with water in a sauce pot  over medium heat until warm.
3. In same skillet, add remaining butter. Add diced onions and garlic, sauté for 3-4 mins until slightly golden brown. Add preserved lemon paste. 
4. Pour in arborio rice and toss until coated w/ onion-garlic mixture, about 2 mins. Add rosemary.
5. Add one ladle (about 1/3 cup) miso broth to the rice at a time, stirring consistently over medium low heat. Repeat this step, adding 1/3 cup of broth at a time, until no more broth is left and the rice is cooked. This should take about 18-20 minutes, stirring consistently.
6. Once risotto is tender, add in drained can of beans and cheese. Let simmer for 5 minutes. Add salt/pepper if needed.
7. Garnish with drizzle of Extra Virgin olive oil, more cheese, sumac, and fresh pepper

#risotto #weeknightmeals #comfortfood #artichokes #vegetarianrecipes

Scallion Pancake 🤝 Breakfast Egg Sandwich (Recipe Below ⬇️) with my favorite plant-based egg @justegg 

If there’s one thing my last relationship gifted me, it was weekly trips to Win Son, a Taiwanese bakery in Brooklyn that whipped out the most fire traditional scallion pancake breakfast sandwiches. 

But a new year brings new energy for GOOD change. So instead we recreate it at home with a little plant-forward twist. Scallion pancakes are a delicious, flaky vessel for the most perfect veggie-forward toppings like my fav, @justegg, and seasoned veggies

Here’s how to make it:
Scallion Pancake
- 2 cups all-purpose flour
- 1/2 tsp salt
- 3/4 cup boiling water
Filling
- 1/3 cup AP flour
- 1/4 cup olive oil
- 1 tbsp za’atar (not traditional & optional)
- 3/4 teaspoon salt
- 8 to 10 scallions, slice lengthwise then chopped

Soft-Scrambled Eggs
- 6 tbsp Just Egg
- 1 tbsp butter
- pinch of sea salt/pepper

Zesty Greens
- 1/2 cup roughly chopped kale
- 1/4 red onion, thinly sliced
- juice of 1 lemon
- drizzle of pomegranate molasses, optional

Seared Chestnut Mushrooms
- 4oz mushrooms
- 1 tablespoon olive oil
- salt/pepper to taste

Process:
1.  Combine flour & salt in a bowl. Slowly stir in the hot water using a fork or chopsticks (1/4 cup at a time). Dough will be flakey to start. Press dough together using hands in a kneading motion. Add a little more water if there is dry flour is remaining. Knead the dough for 5 mins until smooth (some imperfections in the dough are okay). Cover the dough & let rest for 30 mins.
2. Combine flour, olive oil, salt, & za’atar until combined. Slice scallions & set aside.
3. After dough has rested, knead until smooth. Cut dough into 6 even pieces & form into a smooth ball. Work with 1 ball at a time, covering the rest so they don’t dry out. Roll each ball into a thin-ish rectangle (about 6”x10”). Brush some of the flour-oil mixture onto most of the dough (avoiding the edges). Sprinkle 2 tbsp scallions on top. Roll the dough from one side until you form a long tube. Pinch the edges then twist into a tight 🌀, tucking the end into the back center of the swirl. (recipe cont’d in comment

♥️Ginger Olive Oil Cake 🤝 Beet Swirl: because we need the vibrancy and a little grounding energy (literally) 

This might be quite literally the most moist, fluffy, VOLUPTUOUS cake I’ve ever made. The crumb is light and airy with a sweeet earthy floral ribbon of beet-ginger cake batter. It’s extra, like me (a gemini rising) 

Make this for yourself- and maybe someone you’re trying to impress if they deserve it 🤝

Here’s how to make it:
4oz of beets roasted w/ 2 tbsp olive oil
2 tbsp minced ginger
4 tbsp sugar
1/2 cup oat milk
1/2 cup lemon juice
2 tbsp lemon zest
4 eggs (or egg substitute), beaten
1 cup olive oil
1/2 tsp almond extract
2 1/2 cup AP flour
2 tsp ground ginger
2 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp baking soda 
1 tsp kosher salt
1 cup white sugar

(Lemon Glaze)
1 3/4 cup confectioners’ sugar
3 tbsp lemon juice
1/4 tsp fine sea salt
1 tbsp melted butter

Process:

1. Preheat oven to 400F. Rinse beets and peel, then cut into quarters. Toss with olive oil on aluminum foil and wrap. Place on a sheet tray and roast in middle rack for 35-45 mins, until fork tender. Remove and let beets cool. 
2. To a food processor, puree the beets, minced ginger, 4 tbsp sugar until a smooth-ish paste comes to fruition (consistency should be slightly pulpy)
3. In a bowl, whisk together flour, ginger powder, baking soda/powder, salt, and sugar. Set aside.
4. Mix together lemon zest, juice, and milk. Let sit for 5 mins. Beat eggs (or egg substitute like JUST egg) until frothy. Combine milk and eggs. Whisk in olive oil and heat until light and airy. Mix in almond extract.
5. Make a well in the bowl of the dry ingredients and pour in the wet. Whisk until combined and fluffy. 
6. Remove 1 cup batter and combine with beet-ginger puree. 
7. To a greased 8in bundt pan (mine is from ikea), pour in about 1/3 of the batter. Dollop the beet batter on top. Use a skewer to swirl it together. Repeat 2-3x until no more batter remains
8. Bake in a preheated 325F oven in the middle rack for 40-50 mins until a toothpick comes out clean when inserted in the cake
9. Garnish with lemon glaze and sumac.

#oliveoilcake #easybaking #cakesofinstagram #desserttable #beets

🥞The perfect pancake…exists and it’s these Squash-Pandan Pancakes w/ Chocolate Yogurt Mousse🤝 (RECIPE BELOW ⬇️)

I will perish on the hill that pancakes are superior to waffles. 🧍🏽The perfect vessel. The apple of my eye. The stack I want to be on at all times. It welcomes so many different flavors & combinations. It also doesn’t require ANOTHER machine to take up the real estate in our shoebox of a kitchen.

My favorite way to make pancakes a little more filling and protein rich (especially important for my plant-based girlies who may not get enough in the day) is by adding extra layers of flavor in between, like a protein chocolate mousse. I’ve been obsessed w/ @gardenoflife new Oatmilk Chocolate Protein that’s a bit easier to digest and truly A DELIGHT to eat. As always you can use “LAHBCO20” for 20% because I just want you to save some coin 🥹♥️ #golpartner

Anywho, here’s how you make it😋

Pancakes
3/4 cup flour
1 tbsp sugar
1/2 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp baking soda
pinch of salt
1 egg or egg substitute
1/2 tsp pandan extract (sub almond or vanilla extract)
1/4 cup squash/pumpkin/sweet potato puree
1/4 cup oatmilk + 2 tbsp lemon juice

Chocolate Protein Mousse:
1/4 cup yogurt of choice
1 scoop @gardenoflife Oatmilk Chocolate Protein Powder
1 tbsp cocoa powder (for double chocolate energy)
Pinch of sea salt

Process:

1. Mix together the oatmilk and lemon juice. Set aside
2. Sift together the flour, sugar, baking powder/soda and salt in a bowl. Add the oatmilk-lemonjuice mixture, egg, puree and whisk until combined and
 light/airy, about 2 mins. Whisk in the pandan (or vanilla extract). 
3. Heat a non-stick skillet over medium-low heat. A true non-stick does not need to be greased! Using a 1/4 cup, cook pancakes 1-2 at a time until golden, about 2 min.
4. Mix together yogurt, protein powder, cocoa powder, and sea salt.
5. Stack yogurt in between every pancakes. Garnish w/ fruit and maple syrup.

#pancakes #plantbasedbreakfast #weekendbreakfast #pandan #healthybreakfast

Carrots 🤝 Murasaki Potatoes: Pure bliss that you can spread on anything, and that’s self-love🤰(Recipe Below ⬇️)

This root veggie spread uses two of my favorite vegetables- the mighty carrot and the robust, full of flavor, party girl- the Murasaki Sweet Potato

It’s sweet and savory, with warm notes of floral coriander and tangy sumac.

Serve this with bread, use it as a base for a scramble bowl, or add it to thicken a sandwich. Here’s how you make it:
- 1-lb **Murasaki potatoes, rinsed**
- 1lb carrots, peeled
- **zest of one lemon**
- juice of 1 lemon
- 1/3 cup **tahini**
- 1/2 cup **extra-virgin olive oil**
- 2 tbsp **maple syrup**
- 1/2 tsp **sumac**, a*dd more if needed*
- 1/2 tsp **cayenne pepper**, a*dd more if needed*
- 1/2 tsp coriander, a*dd more if needed*
- about 1/2 tsp **sea salt**, *add more if needed*
- **drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil,** *for garnish*
1. Preheat your oven to 400. Rinse potatoes/carrots and wrap in aluminum foil separately. Roast them in middle rack until fork tender (about 45 mins). Once roasted, let cool and remove the peel (I personally love to snack on them by dipping them in my favorite nut butter).
2. To a food processor or high-speed blender, add potatoes and carrots, lemon zest, tahini, olive oil, maple syrup, sumac, cayenne pepper, coriander, and salt.
3. Blend until smooth. If too thick, add 1-2 tbsp water at a time until desired consistency. Adjust the seasoning per your taste by adding more salt/coriander/cayenne/sumac if needed.
4. Once smooth, pour into a dish. Drizzle a heaping of fresh, good-quality extra-virgin olive oil.
5. Garnish with fennel pickled onions, pomegranate seeds, sumac. 
6. Grab crusty bread and dive in!

#dips #carrots #sweetpotato #vegansnacks #easyveganrecipes #comfortfood

🇲🇦🫘Loubia (Moroccan White Beans) in pot pie form, because everything is better with better with crispy golden tops 🫠

These white beans are seen throughout North Africa in so many different formats. They’re spiced with the most warming aromas and a texture that beautifully coats your throat- a great alternative if you’re in a dry spell.🤭

It’s honestly the perfect dish to make for friends or as the star of any table begging for a plant-based dish to “ooh” and “ahh” about 🫡

Here’s how to make it:
* 3 cans of cannellini beans
* (1) 15-ounce can of crushed tomatoes
* 1 medium yellow onion, diced
* 6 garlic cloves, minced
* 1/3 cup olive oil
* 3 tablespoons fresh parsley, chopped
* 3 tablespoons fresh cilantro, chopped
* 1 tsp kosher salt, add more to taste
* 2 tablespoons tomato paste
* 1/2 tablespoon cumin
* 2 teaspoons ginger
* 1 teaspoon cinnamon
* 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg
* 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper (optional)
* 8oz maitake mushrooms, shredded
* juice of 1 lemon
* 5 to 6 sheets of phyllo, room temp
* chopped parsley, for garnish
* lemon zest, for garnish
* drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil, for garnish
1. Preheat oven to 350F if adding phyllo on top. In a large pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add onions and garlic;sauté for 5 minutes until slightly softened and translucent. Add tomato paste and spices (ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, cumin, and cayenne pepper). Sauté until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add shredded maiitake mushrooms and toss to coat.
2. Add the canned beans (WITH LIQUID), canned tomato, chopped herbs and salt. Bring to a simmer, cover and cook for about 20 minutes.
3. Taste and adjust seasoning; add more salt or spices based on preference. Stir in lemon juice. Let simmer for additional 5 minutes.
4. If serving as is, garnish w/ olive oil, chopped herbs and serve with crusty bread.
5. If serving as a pot pie, layer 5 to 6 sheets of phyllo. Scrunching one sheet a time and brushing with melted butter after every sheet. Score the top of the phyllo into angled sections (think of a top pie crust). Bake for 25-30 minutes or until golden.

#beans #potpie #vegandinnerideas #moroccanfood #northafricanfood #loubia

I’ve eaten this everyday for the past 10 days… and i wont stop, i fear 🍚🤝

Congee is a staple throughout East Asia- the smooth, silky texture of rice porridge is the perfect meal to cozy up to as you watch yet another rom-com

My first experience with congee was in the dead HEAT of August in 2017 when my roommate T made a batch as our first home cooked meal together. I sweat my as$ off and felt even better for it.

Gosavory- devour it with some sweet toppings. Just make it- here’s how:
Congee 
-1 cup jasmine rice, briefly rinsed
-1/2 cup farro
-3 star anise
-4 cardamom pods
-1/2 tsp salt
Harissa Maple Marinade
-2 tbsp harissa
-2 tbsp maple syrup
-1 tbsp soy sauce
-1 tbsp rice vinegar
-1 tbsp olive oil
-4oz maitake mushrooms, or protein of choice (shrimp, shredded chicken, etc)
Process
1. In a large pot, add the rice, farro, star anise, cardamom pods, salt, and 7 cups water. Bring to a boil over medium high heat then reduce to a simmer and partially cover.
2. Cook for 45 minutes-1 hour, stirring every 10 to 15 mins. If you desire a thinner consistency, add about 1 more cup of water halfway through the cooktime. If a thicker consistency is desired, continue cooking without the lid for the last 10 minutes.
3. To make the marinade: Whisk together the harissa, maple syrup, soy sauce, vinegar, and oil. Shred the maitake mushrooms with your hands. Cook the mushrooms in an ungreased skillet over medium heat to remove the moisture, about 5 minutes. Add a drizzle of olive oil over the mushrooms and stir in the glaze. Cook until slightly caramelized.
4. Garnish congee w/ mushrooms, sauteed kale (bok choy works great too), sesame seeds, and your favorite chili oil

#congee #porridge #breakfastideas #comfortfood #ricebowl

Za’atar Coated Maduros 🇵🇷🫡 bring some extra flavor to the snack table this weekend.

If you’re watching the super bowl (read: Rihanna Half Time Show) this weekend, this is what you should be snacking on to distract yourself for the first half of the evening. 🤝

Maduros are a staple snack I grew up eating with my childhood friends. It was super affordable and quick to make for a handful of ravenous kids that my mom whipped out weekly.

I love adding a little spice blend like za’atar or some cumin/cayenne for a texture-flavor story with every bite ♥️

Here’s how to make it:
* 2 ripe yellow plantains
* 2 tbsp coconut oil
* 1/2 tbsp za’atar
* 1/4 tsp cumin
* 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper
* 1/2 tsp sea salt
Tahini Mojo Sauce
* 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil
* 1 tbsp tahini
* Juice of 2 limes
* Juice of 1 juicing orange
* 4 garlic cloves, finely minced
* 1 tbsp chopped dill
* 1 tbsp chopped mint
* 1/4 tsp ground cumin
* 1/2 tsp salt/pepper, to taste
{Za’atar Maduros}
1. Cut the ends off your ripe. Lightly use the tip of your knife to make a single slit on the peel vertically. Remove the peel.
2. At an angle, cut the plantain into 1 1/2“ slices and place in a bowl. Toss with 2 tbsp of coconut oil, or another high smoke point neutral oil like avocado oil, and spices.
3. Two Ways of Cooking (Traditional Method and Air Fry): To cook the traditional method, add about 1” to 2” of frying oil (like vegetable oil) to a heavy-bottomed skillet. Heat over medium heat. Place the maduros down on one side and flip when golden. Repeat and place on a paper-lined tray. To cook via air-fryer, place the maduros in the air fryer evenly. Cook for 10-12 minutes at 380F
4. Once cooked, add to a bowl and toss w/ another sprinkle of za’atar
 {Tahini Garlic Mojo Dipping Sauce}
1. In a bowl, mix the extra virgin olive oil, tahini, lime juice (I like to use the prongs of a fork in a twisting motion to help get all the juice from the lime), orange juice, minced garlic cloves, cumin, salt/pepper to taste and cilantro.
2. Stir until evenly combined. Taste and adjust the seasoning per your preference. 
8.Dip and dive in!

Matcha. Orange Blossom. Olive Oil. Cake. 🎂 🍵 

My version of a love cake- with some added caffeine to keep you up while you prowl through these STREETS

This cake reminds me that we’re all a lot like the cooking/baking process. The most scrumptious things come from intention, time, and quality ingredients (including people)- and it’s even better when shared with others. So make this and share it with those who show up for YOU the same whag you show up for them ♥️

1/4 cup oat milk
1/4 cup lemon juice
2 tbsp lemon zest
2 eggs (or egg substitute), beaten
1/2 cup olive oil
1 tbsp orange blossom water
1 1/4 cup AP flour
2 tbsp matcha powder
1 tsp baking powder
1/8 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp kosher salt
3/4 cup white sugar

Orange blossom CC Frosting
6 oz cream cheese, softened
6 tbsp softened unsalted butter
2 1/2 cup powdered sugar
1 tbsp orange blossom water
1/4 tsp cardamom
Pinch of flaky salt

Process:
1. Preheat oven to 325F. Grease and line a 8inch cake pan.
2. In a bowl, whisk together flour, matcha, baking soda/powder, salt, and sugar. Set aside.
3. Mix together lemon zest, juice, and milk. Let sit for 5 mins. Beat eggs (or egg substitute like JUST egg) until frothy. Combine milk and eggs. Whisk in olive oil and heat until light and airy. Mix in orange blossom water
4. Make a well in the bowl of the dry ingredients and pour in the wet. Whisk until combined and fluffy.
5. Bake in the middle rack for 25-35 mins until a toothpick comes out clean when inserted in the cake. Remove and let cool on a sheet tray.
6. Make CC frosting: Cream together CC and butter until combined. Add powdered sugar 1/2 cup at a time. Add salt, cardamom, and orange blossom water and cream until combined. If you want a thicker CC frosting, add an additional 1/2c powdered sugar. Add more cardamom or orange blossom to taste.
7.  Garnish with cc frosting. 

#matcha #vegandessert #oliveoilcake #lovecake #dessertlover #creamcheesefrosting

Use that dusty ol’ cabbage in the back of your fridge and make SOUP 😌🥣

Red cabbage is one of my favorite veggies during the winter. Vibrant, versatile, a true texture story. Here’s how to make it!

1lb cabbage, thinly sliced into ribbons
1 yellow onion, diced
3 garlic cloves
3 tablespoons olive oil
1 tsp cinnamon
1/4 tsp allspice kernels
5 cloves
1/2 tsp sumac
3 cups water
1 (15-ounce) can of white beans, liquid included
1 cup coconut cream
salt/pepper, to taste
Directions:
1. Slice cabbage into ribbons, dice onion, and mince garlic. Heat olive oil over medium heat in a pot.
2. Saute onions until fragrant, about 3 to 4 minutes. Add spices and garlic. Saute for another 1 minute until fragrant.
3. Add cabbage to pot with about 1/2 tsp salt. Stir and cook for about 7-8 minutes until wilted. Add 3 cups water and can of white beans (liquid included). Bring to a boil, then lower to a simmer and cook for 20 minutes.
4. Using an immersion blender, blend the soup until smooth. If using a stand blender, let soup cool prior to blending (no accidents here)
5. Add coconut cream to soup, and season with additional salt/pepper
6. Garnish w/ a drizzle of yogurt, fresh cracked pepper, and dill. Take as a shot, serve with bread, and enjoy the last days of soup szn.

#soupseason #redcabbage #easyveganmeals #dinnerideas #soups

🍀💚🌱🥦❇️ Super Greens Pasta is better than super greens smoothie !

If this time of year brings some sort of angst about diet culture and unwavering emotions about reaching some unrealistic body goal rooted in euro-centric beauty standards- remember that as a collective we’re shifting from Either/Or mindsets to Both/And.

That includes greens, nutritious ingredients, carbs, and sweets alike. It’s all about balance and doing your body AND mind good. And sometimes a fat a$s plate of pasta smothered in greens is a great base for a sweet treat before bed. 

Here’s how to make it:
* 2 tbsp olive oil
* 1 in Ginger
* 1 shallot, minced
* 4 garlic cloves, minced
* 1 tsp cumin
* 1/2 cup chopped Mint
* 1 cup chopped parsley
* 2 cup Peas
* 1 cup spinach
* 1 1/3 cup coconut cream
* Zest of 1 lime, juice of 2 limes
* 8 oz fettuccine noodles
* 1/4 cup Parmigiano reggiano
 Directions:
1. Bring a pot of waster to simmer. Add frozen peas and spinach, cook until bright green about 2 mins, remove and chill in cold water.
2. In a skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat. Sautéed shallot, ginger, garlic until fragrant, about 2-3 mins. Add cumin and sauce for 1 min.
3. Add chopped mint and parsley. Toss to coat, then drain peas/mint and add to skillet. Sauce for 2 mins then add coconut cream, lime zest/juice
4. Add about 1/4 tsp salt and pepper. The sauce should lack a little bit of salt because the pasta water we reserve will season the sauce as well.
5. Heavily salt water in a pot and bring to a boil. Cook noodle of choice to al dente. Reserve 1/2 cup pasta water.
6. Add pasta to sauce with parmigiana reggiano and 1/4 cup pasta water, to start. Stir to emulsify and glossy.
7. Plate and garnish with more cheese, parsley, and harissa (this is non-negotiable)

#pasta #easyweeknightmeals #plantbasedrecipes #vegetables

Fried Delicata Squash Rings ⭕️ a sweeter version to the (my) emotional support onion ring.

These squash rings are HEAVILY inspired by the perfectly crispy, crunchy delicata squash rings I INHALED (as one does) from @shukettenyc last fall. 

As munchy march quickly approaches, and shit continuously hitting the fan- we need more snacks than ever to keep us company (after we hit our gummies 💨🍃)

Here’s how to make my version of them: 
1/2 cup corn flour
1/2 cup ap flour
2 tbsp ras el hanout
1 tbsp cornstarch
3 tbsp black sesame seeds
1 cup seltzer water
2 delicata squash, sliced into 1/2” rings, seeds removed
(Aji Verde)
3/4 cup raw unsalted cashews, *soaked in boiling water for 30 mins*
3/4 cup cashew soaking liquid
1 bunch cilantro
2 jalapenos, *charred skin, stem, and seeds removed (traditionally made w/ Aji Amarillo)*
2 garlic cloves
1 tbsp white miso paste
Juice of 1 lime
salt, to taste

Process:

1. Clean your squash, slice, and put aside. To a deep-wide bowl, whisk together cornflour, ap flour, ras el hanout, cornstarch, and sesame seeds until combined. Add seltzer water and whisk until smooth. 
2. Heat about 2 cups of high-smoke point oil in a deep pan over medium heat. Coat  squash rings in batter using a fork and carefully place into hot oil. Cook about 4 at a time until golden, about 2 mins per side. Remove from oil and drain on paperlined plate. Sprinkle w/ a good pinch of flaky salt
3. To make Aji Verde, soak cashews for 30 mins in boiling water. Char jalapenos on the stove under medium heat by placing it on the stove grate or roast in oven for 20 mins at 400F. Place in a bowl and cover for 5 mins to create condensation. Remove charred skin and stem. Blend together soaked cashews, cashew soaking liquid, cilantro, jalapenos, garlic, miso, lime juice, and salt (to taste) until smooth
4. Dunk squash rings into sauce and dive in!

#snacks #vegansnacks #friedfood #delicatasquash #easyveganrecipes

🧎🍲Sometimes all you need is clean-out-the-fridge soup... like this Coconut Mushroom and Dumpling one

Now most of the US is going through some dramatic weather event, it’s important now, more than ever, to make sure you’re using the food you have in your fridge that’s wilting away faster than my attention span & making a meal that is perfect to freeze, dump and serve whenever you need to.

This is loosely inspired by my favorite Thai Soup., Tom Kha Gai & the American staple, chicken & dumpling... sans 🐥

Here’s how to make it:
2 leeks, 
3 garlic cloves, minced
2 inch ginger, minced
8oz of mixed mushrooms, chopped/shredded
4 carrots, sliced
1 1/2 tbsp garam masala
1 (15oz) can white beans
2 (15oz) cans full-fat coconut milk
1 tbsp white miso
juice of 2 lemons, zest of 1 lemon
1 tbsp sugar
(Semolina dumplings)
1/2 cup AP flour
1/2 cup coarse semolina 
1 tbsp sugar
1 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 tsp black pepper
1/3 cup oat milk
juice of 1/2 lemon (2 tbsp)
1 tbsp salted butter, melted
Process:

1. Make dumplings by mixing together the dry ingredients in a bowl until combined. Add milk, lemon juice, & butter & stir until combined. Cover w/ a cloth & set aside to rest while making soup
2. Slice leeks to separate the base from the leaves. Halve & slice the leek bottoms into thin strands. Thoroughly clean the leaves to remove any grime, layer each leaf on one another, then slice into ribbons & set aside.
3. In a pot, heat 3 tbsp olive oil over medium heat. Add sliced leek bottoms, ginger, & garlic. Saute until fragrant & leeks have wilted, about 3-4 mins. Add garam masala, toss to coat, & cook until fragrant, about 1 min.
4. Add the carrots, leek leaves, & mushrooms (button, maitake, shiitake, baby bella) with, both cans of coconut milk, beans & 1 cup water. Season with salt (about 1/2 tsp) & let simmer for 15 mins. 
5. Stir in miso paste, lemon juice/zest, & sugar. Taste & adjust seasoning if needed (salt/pepper/etc)
6. Using a large spoon, take even scoops of the dumpling batter & drop it into the soup. Stir, cover, & cook partially covered for an additional 5 mins.
7. Serve w/ parm cheese, dill, & pepper.

#soup #coconutmilk #vegancomfortfood #soupseason

THE only brunch you need to me this weekend: Savory Veggie Pancakes— 3 Ways 🥬🧅🥞

As a self-proclaimed dessert breakfast person, savory pancakes have found love in a hopeless place (my heart)

These are a great way to clean out your fridge and all the veggie scraps left behind and make a savory take on the classic American breakfast staple

Here’s how to make it:
1/2 cup all purpose flour
2 tbsp cornstarch
11/2 tsp baking powder
1 egg
1/2 cup plant-based milk, room temperature
1 tbsp lemon juice
2 tbsp melted butter (vegan or reg)
1/2 tsp turmeric, optional
1/2 tsp garlic, recommended 
(Sautéed Cabbage)
1 cup thinly sliced red cabbage
1 tsp mala spice
(Sumac-Leeks)
1 leek, stem halved and sliced (remove leaves)
1/2 tsp sumac
Pinch of salt
(Zesty Snap Peas)
4oz snap peas
Zest of 1 lemon
Pinch of salt

Process:
1. Prep and cook veggies: Thinly slice cabbage, halve and slice leeks, and/or trim ends of snap peas. {To cook cabbage} Add cabbage to the pan and season w/ salt, saute for 1 min until softened. Add mala spice mix and sauté for another minute. Remove from pan. {To cook leeks} Saute leeks in 1 tbsp olive oil w/ pinch of salt until softened. Add sumac and saute for additional 2-3 mins. Remove from pan. {To cook snap peas} Sautéed snap peas in 1 tbsp olive oil until blistered on both sides, about 2 mins. Add lemon zest and toss to coat. Remove from heat.
2. To make the batter: In a bowl, combine flour, cornstarch, baking powder,  garlic powder, and turmeric. In a separate bowl, combine the milk, lemon juice, egg, and melted butter until combined. Whisk in the liquids to the dry mixture until combined.
3. Use about 1/4c of batter for each pancake.  Sprinkle or place the cooked veggies on each pancake or mix the batter into each bowl of sautéed veggies. (For the leeks, I like to combine the leeks and batter like the mixture for latke. For the Cabbage/Snap Peas, I like to place them on top of the uncooked batter once poured onto the pan.)Cook on both sides, about 1-2 mins each.

#pancakes #veggies #savorypancakes #brunchideas #easybreakfastideas

🥗🫰🏼An easier version of the Miso Veggie Bowl, for the time inept and working gurls.

Every year I make this salad, and every year I’m reminded that you really can make a fire salad at home for less… no tea, no shade but saving money tastes better

Here’s how to make it:

* 1 lb squash, peeled and cut into cubes
* 1/2 lb sweet potato, peeled and cut into cubes
* 1 red onion, cut into quarters
* 8oz tempeh, crumbled
* 3 tbsp olive oil
Dressing
* 2 tbsp white miso paste
* 2 tbsp tahini 
* 1 tbsp sesame oil 
* 1 tbsp maple syrup
* Juice of 1 lemon
* 1/2 tbsp minced ginger
* 1 garlic clove, minced
* 1/2 to 1 tsp harissa spice, substitute w/ pinch of cayenne and cumin
* salt and pepper, to taste
* Splash water, to thin
To arrange
* Greens of choice
* Wild rice
* Cabbage
* Feta cheese, crumbled

Process:
1. Preheat oven to 400F. Peel and chop veggies and add to a bowl with crumbled tempeh. Toss w/ 3 tbsp olive and season with salt/pepper. Place on 2 lined trays and roast for 25-30 mins until tender. Remove and let cool.
2. In a bowl, whisk together dressing ingredients until combined, adding water to thin it out if needed. Add more harissa or cayenne for more of a kick. Pour 1/4 cup of this glaze over the veggies and toss to coat. 
3. Arrange on top of arugula, alongside sliced cabbage, wild rice (or quinoa), and any other toppings your heart desires. 
4. Add feta and more dressing and dive in!

Moroccan Chermoula 🤝Baked Beans 🤝
Pot Pie (RECIPE BELOW ⬇️)

This quick weeknight meal blossomed from one too many cans of beans, 2/$1 cilantro and parsley, and sheer end-of-winter boredom. 

Chermoula is one of my favorite condiments from Morocco. It’s herby, bright, potent (in the most effervescent way), and the perfect way to add a punch of flavor to something bland and boring like beans (read: your ex)

Here’s how to make it:
* (3) 15-ounce cans of cannellini beans, drained
* 2 cups parsley, stems/leaves roughly chopped
* 2 cups cilantro, stems/leaves roughly chopped
* 5 cloves garlic, minced
* 1 tsp cumin
* 1/4 tsp pepper 
* 1/2 tsp salt 
* 1/2 preserved lemon, minced
* juice of 2 lemon
* 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil (add additional 2 tablespoons if needed)
* 4 tbsp water, if needed
* 1 (15-ounce) can of coconut cream, solids only, water discarded
* 1/4 cup all-purpose flour
* 10 to 12 sheets phyllo dough
* 4 tbsp unsalted butter, melted
* 1 tbsp granulated sugar
* 1 tbsp harissa spice, optional

1. Preheat oven to 350F. Make chermoula: If using a food processor/immersion blender: Add the roughly chopped parsley/cilantro, minced garlic, ground cumin, ground black pepper, kosher salt, cayenne, pepper, minced preserved lemon, lemon juice, olive oil, and water. Blend until smooth. Taste and adjust the seasoning per your personal preference. 
2. Drain beans and add to a large bowl. Add the chermoula and coconut cream (be sure to separate the coconut fat solids from the liquid in the can of coconut cream). Sift in 1/4 cup flour and mix until combined. 
3. Pour into a 9-inch pie pan. Take 1 sheet of phyllo dough and scrunch it into an accordion shape. Place on top of the beans on one end, and repeat with the remaining phyllo sheets, placing one scrunched sheet next to another until the beans are fully covered. Brush and drizzle the melted butter evenly over the phyllo. Sprinkle the sugar and harissa spice on top.
4. Bake on the middle rack for 20 minutes or until the crust is golden brown.
5. Dive in!

#moroccanfood #bakedbeans #phyllo #chermoula #easydinnerideas

in pi day we trust… if you don’t like banana cream pie— grow up! & try this one 🍌🥧 (RECIPE ⬇️)

the first time I attempted to make banana cream pie was in 2018 during my internship’s office pie day pie-off. it was a major flop & a half

but we’ve resurrected her from the vault & added some flair, depth, & effervescence to make it the perfect pie worth eating for breakfast (cause fruit, you know?)

here’s how to make it:
(Crust)
1 1/2 cups  rolled oats
1/2 cups sesame seeds (untoasted if baking crust, toasted if no-bake crust)
6-7 tbsp unsalted butter, melted
2 tbsp sugar
1/2 tsp salt
1-2 tbsp ice-cold water
(Tahini Cream Pudding)
2 cups milk of choice (I used oat milk)
1/4 cup cornstarch, sifted
1/2 tsp salt
1 tbsp orange blossom water
2/3 cup tahini
2 tbsp unsalted butter
1/2 cup confectioner’s sugar
(Assembly)
3-4 bananas, sliced
Non-dairy whipped topping
Process:
1. Make pudding: in a bowl whisk together milk, cornstarch, confectioner’s sugar, salt, & orange blossom until combined. Pour into a saucepan & heat over med heat. Cook for about 5 minutes, stirring consistently. Add the 2 tbsp of butter & continue stirring until the pudding begins to thicken (it should be able to coat/stick to the back of a spoon when dipped). Once pudding thickens, stir in tahini.
2. Pour into a glass bowl & cover with plastic wrap & prep plastic wrap on top of the surface of the pudding to avoid a film from forming. Refrigerate for 1 hour or freeze for about 30 minutes.
3. Make the crust: If baking it, preheat oven to 375F. In a food processor, combine oats, sesame seeds, sugar, & salt until fine. Add 8 tbsp of melted butter & pulse into a crumbly consistency.
4. Press the filling into a 9-inch pie pan. Bake for 16-18 mins until golden or freeze for 1 hour.
5. Once the crust & pudding have cooled, slice 2 bananas diagonally. Layer bananas on the bottom of pie. Pour in 1/2 pudding. Layer with bananas again, & cover w/ remaining pudding. Cover with plastic wrap & refrigerate for 4 hours, preferably overnight.
6. Once pudding has set, garnish w/ cool whip then sliced bananas.

#pie #bananacreampie #vegandessert

Eat more cabbage (with eggs), your wallet will thank you. Here’s how <3 (RECIPE BELOW ⬇️)

I’ve been obsessed with my cabbage era, and you should have your own. During the winter, when fresh produce is slim and barren like dating scene, cabbages are one of my favorite ways to inject some vibrancy and fun into my diet.

It also appens to be incredibly nutritious, affordable, and delicious— the traits of a legend. Sauteeing the cabbage with warm spices like cardamom, cinnamon, and ginger brings out a little kick and amps up the natural sweetness it has. Add some eggs for shakshuka vibes and this is a one-pot meal you can make while you still have the spins

Here’s how to make it:
1/2 head of red cabbage, thinly sliced (root removed)
3 tbsp olive oil
1/2 red onion, thinly sliced
2 garlic cloves, minced
1/2 tsp cinnamon
1/2 tsp garlic powder
1/2 tsp ginger
1/4 tsp cardamom
salt to taste (about 1/4 tsp to start)
juice of 1 lemon
1 tbsp sugar
4 eggs

Process:
1. Thinly slice cabbage, red onion, and mince garlic. In a skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat. Saute onion and garlic until softened, about 2 mins.
2. Add the spices and saute until fragrant. Add cabbage and season with salt. The salt will draw out some moisture to help it cook down. Toss and saute and cook for 4 to 5 mins, until wilted. 
3. Add the lemon juice and sugar and 1/4 cup of water, then toss to coat. Taste and adjust seasoning. Create 4 vessels and drop an egg in each one. Cover and cook for about 3 to 4 mins until the egg whites have set but the yolks are still jiggly.
4. Remove from heat and serve immediately. Garnish w/ hot sauce/aji verde, parsley, flakey salt and pepper

#cabbage #easybreakfastideas #shakshuka

🇲🇦My favorite snack of all time is Moroccan Stuffed Triangles aka Briouats. Sweet, Savory, Crispy. (Recipe Below ⬇️)

My grandmother Moey would truly pop off once a week when she would visit us months at a time from Morocco by making these stuffed phyllo triangles. She would fill them with the most incredibly seasoned meat (we’re using mushrooms) or almond paste filling for the sweetest of night caps.

Here’s how I make my version <3:
* 8oz ground vegan beef or baby Bella mushrooms
* 2 to 3 tbsp olive oil
* 1/2 medium onion, finely chopped
* 2 garlic cloves, minced
* 1/2 paprika
* 1/2 tsp cumin
* 1/2 tsp ginger
* 1/2 tsp cinnamon
* 1/4 tsp cayenne
* Salt and pepper to taste (about 1/2 tsp)
* 1/4 cup finely chopped parsley
* 2 tbsp butter
{Assembly}
* Phyllo Dough, about 6 sheets 
* 4 to 6 tbsp butter or olive oil
* 2 to 3 tbsp honey, optional 
* sesame seeds, optional 

Process
1. If baking, preheat oven to 400F.
2. Heat olive oil in a skillet over med heat. Saute mushrooms for about 2 mins. Add onion, garlic, and spices. Toss to coat and saute for about 4 to 5 mins. Once fragrant, add the chopped parsley and butter; saute for 2 mins. Remove from heat
3. Roll out your stack of phyllo dough sheets and work with 2 layers at a time. Place the phyllo sheets vertically. Using a sharp knife, cut the 2 layers into 4 even strips.
4. Add 1 heaping tbsp of filling at the bottom of each strip, leaving a flap at the end to secure the meat. Fold that flap over to enclose the meat. To create the triangular shape, fold the bottom right corner of the dough towards the upper left until it meets the left edge of the phyllo sheet. Be sure to enclose any parts of the dough that reveal the meat by gently pressing down around the edge. 
5. Continue folding in that pattern, folding from left to right, until you use the entire strip of phyllo. 
6. Brush the edge of the dough with butter and fold over the remaining flap.
7. Place the briouats on a greased baking sheet and bake on each side for 5 to 6 mins or until golden. Brush with honey, garnish with sesame seeds, and serve with your favorite spicy sauce!

#moroccanfood #vegansnacks #mushrooms

🥕🎂This take on BRAZILIAN CARROT CAKE is the only carrot cake worth making… (RECIPE BELOW) ⬇️ 

I take carrot cake very seriously & very personally. Using the Brazilian technique for their “bolo de cenoura” ensures a moist crumb, a gorgeous hue, & nutty aroma.

My favorite part about carrot cake is its versatility. This one is egg-free thanks to my favorite egg substitute, @gardenoflife Golden Milled Flaxseed that brings super omega-3’s as much as it brings structure & body to the cake. It’s a must ;’) As always, you can use “LAHBCO20” for 20% your first purchase. #golpartner

Remember to use those critical thinking skills & add whatever frosting or fillings you prefer 🫦

Here’s how to make it!
- 200g peeled carrots, cut into chunks (about 3-4 carrots)
- 2 tbsp @gardenoflife Golden Milled Flaxseed + 6 tbsp water
- 3/4 cup + 2 tbsp white sugar
- 2/3 cup @gardenoflife Raw Extra Virgin coconut oil, melted
- 1/2 tsp coconut extract
- 1 cup, 3 tbsp all-purpose flour
- 2 tbsp cornstarch
- 2 tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp cinnamon
-1/2 tsp ginger
- 1/2 tsp nutmeg
- 1/2 tsp salt
-1/4 cup chopped pistachios,
-1/2 cup of raisins soaked in 1 cup of amaretto liqu0r, wine, or apple juice
- Coconut Cream Cheese Frosting (recipe in comments)
Directions:
1. If using raisins, soak them in your liquid of choice for 2 to 3 hours, preferably overnight.
2. Preheat oven to 350F. Make flax eggs. Grease an 8” bundt pan. Set aside.
3. In a bowl, whisk together dry ingredients. Set aside.
4. In a food processor, combine carrots, flax eggs, sugar, coconut extract & coconut oil until smooth. You can leave some carrot shreds if you want some extra texture.
5. Fold wet mixture into the dry until incorporated with no flour remaining. Fold in your mix-ins.
6. Pour batter into cake pan. Bake for 35 to 40 minutes (on the CENTER RACK) until a clean toothpick comes out when inserted in the middle.
7. Let the cake cool for 10 minutes in the pan & transfer to a wire rack for another 1 to 2 hours. 
8. Garnish the cake with the coconut cream cheese frosting, coconut flakes & chopped pistachios

#carrotcake #dessertlover #brazilianfood

🍋🍲This Garlicky-Herby Asparagus Soup was me and my mom’s favorite meal for months at a time in 2015 🫰🏽🫰🏽

It’s light, refreshing, super simple, and plant-based, perfect to kickstart the bright, effervescent essence we’re grasping onto

It’s also packed full of amazing health benefits (Vitamins A, K, Folic Acid) thanks to the asparagus and antioxidants from the ungodly amount of garlic in this— you’re not kissing anyone anyway, so count your blessings <3 

Here’s how to make it:
1 bunch asparagus, ends trimmed
1/2 yellow onion
10 garlic cloves
4 tbsp olive oil or butter
1/2 tsp ginger powder
1/4 tsp white pepper
1/2 tsp salt
1 1/2 cup water
1 tbsp white miso paste
2 lemons, sliced in half
1 1/2 cup water
12 oz coconut milk
1/2 cup chopped parsley
2 lemons, halved
Process:
1. Trim the ends of your asparagus and discard. Cut asparagus into thirds and set aside. Dice yellow onion, and mince garlic.
2. In a medium pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add onions and garlic, and saute until fragrant and softened, about 3 to 4 mins. Add ginger, white pepper, & salt; saute until fragrant, about 1 min.
3. Add water to the pot with miso, and whisk until combined. Add the asparagus; bring to a simmer and cook for 7 to 8 mins until tender.
4. While asparagus cooks: Heat 2 tbsp olive oil over medium heat in cast iron. Place lemons face down and sear for 3 to 4 mins until lightly caramelized. Squeeze the lemons into the soup and blend once more.
5. Stir in the coconut milk and parsley, cook for 2 more mins, then blend with your immersion blender.
6. Taste and adjust the seasoning, adding more salt/white pepper if needed. Garnish w/ briny harissa breadcrumbs, parsley, and cashew crema
7. Dive in!

#asparagus #souprecipe #easyveganrecipes

chocolate mousse for breakfast because the worlds on fire, happy aries 

starting your day off with something that fuels YOUR fire is essential. have a savory bite? make a scramble. have a sweet tooth? have chocolate mousse because you can— and serve it with some fruit 

i’ve been loving @oishii.berry strawberries as a little gift to for myself and loved ones. the new “Koyo” berry is tart & sweet like me 🐈— and perfectly ripe year round. thank you @oishii.berry for donating to @foodeducationfund on behalf of this collaboration and for helping to revolutionize the future of urban agriculture ♥️ #oishiipartner

Here’s how to make it: 
6oz dark chocolate, melted
2 tbsp coconut oil
12 oz silken tofu 
1 tbsp cocoa powder, sifted 
1 tsp vanilla extract
1 tsp orange blossom water
2 tbsp maple syrup
1/2 tsp sea salt
1 tsp instant coffee, optional
1/8 tsp cayenne pepper, optional

Process:
1. Melt dark chocolate in a metal bowl over a pot of boiling water using the double boiler method. Alternatively, microwave the chocolate and stir in 15 second intervals until melted. Add coconut oil and mix until combined
2. In a food processor or blender, blend together the tofu, sifted cocoa powder, vanilla, orange blossom, maple syrup and sea salt until smooth and combined.
3. Add melted chocolate, instant coffee, and cayenne pepper. Blitz one more time until smooth, about 45 seconds
4. Pour into your vessel and cover with plastic wrap so that it touches the surface of the chocolate. Refrigerate overnight
5. Serve with fresh fruit, yogurt, or granola!

Lionsmane Mushroom Burger… to make up for the embarrassment of paying $20 for a mediocre sandwich at a certain clubhouse… 👹

Lionsmane Mushroom is something I’ve been so excited to try since my girl @anishaspice raved about a lionsmane “Crab Cake” burger she had.

It’s quite literally an iconic member of the fungi family with a texture similar to fish and brain benefits that support the cognitive function we desperately need, along with aiding anxiety and depression. I’ll have 3, please. 

Here’s how to make it:
- 8 oz Lion’s Mane mushroom, shredded (substitute with canned tuna/salmon that has been drained)
- 1 egg (or flax egg)
- 1 tbsp labneh/yogurt
- 1 tbsp harissa paste
- 1/2 tsp cumin
- 2 tbsp diced red onion
- 2 tbsp chopped cilantro
- 1/2 cup semolina flour
- 1/4 tsp salt
{Tangy Sesame Slaw}
2 tbsp labneh
1 tbsp toasted sesame oil
juice of 1/2 lemon
1/2 tsp sumac
salt, to taste
1/2 cup cabbage, shredded
2 tbsp chopped cilantro
1 blood orange, 1 cara cara orange, 1 grapefruit, segmented 

Process
1. Hand shred lions mane mushroom or pulse in a food processor until it resembles tuna. In a bowl whisk together egg, labneh, harissa, spices. Add the lions mane and mix until combined. Add semolina flour. Season with salt/pepper. Using a 1/3 cup, make patties out of the filling. Pop in the freezer to chill for 10 mins.
2. While patties chill, make the slaw. In a bowl whisk together labneh, and sesame oil. lemon juice, and sumac. Peel the citrus by using a sharp knife to cut around the flesh and remove the peel and pith so no white membrane is left. Segment the citrus by carefully cutting between each segment and the membrane holding it together. Set citrus aside. Taste and add salt to taste. Add the cabbage, cilantro, and orange segment. Toss to coat and set in the fridge.
3. To cook lionsmane burgers: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a non-stick skillet over med-low heat. Add the burger and sear on both sides until golden/seared, about 3 mins each side. 
4. Serve on brioche bun with slaw and aji verde sauce.

#lionsmanemushroom #lunchideas #mushroomlover

🤌🏼This is the ONLY sauce you’ll need in your fridge… Plant-Based Aji Verde saves lives (read: meals) RECIPE BELOW ⬇️ 

This twist on Aji Verde is a flavorbomb like the mayo-based sauce that’s served alongside many Peruvian dishes, like pollo a la brasa 🇵🇪 

It’s spicy, creamy, rich, and herbaceous— with just enough lime to create THE most balanced condiment for you to dip literally anything into… including your sanity.

Traditionally, it’s made with aji Amarillo, a beautifully fragrant spicy pepper— but instead, we use jalapeño which is more readily available. It’s also made with mayonnaise, cilantro, and lime juice— the perfect balance of salt, fat, and acid. 

If you’re looking for a traditional recipe, check out @acozykitchen — my favorite Peruvian baddie with the most flavorful recipes <3

Here’s how to make it:
3/4 cup raw unsalted cashews, *soaked in boiling water for 30 mins*
3/4 cup cashew soaking liquid
1 bunch cilantro
2 jalapenos, *charred skin, stem, and seeds removed (traditionally made w/ Aji Amarillo)*
2 garlic cloves
1 tbsp white miso paste
Juice of 1 lime
salt, to taste
Process:
1. To make Aji Verde, soak cashews for 30 mins in boiling water. 
2. Char jalapenos on the stove under medium heat by placing it on the stove grate or roast in oven for 20 mins at 400F. Place them in a bowl and cover with a plate or plastic wrap for 5 mins to create condensation which will make it easier to remove the skin. Remove charred skin and stem. If you want less heat, remove some of the seeds as well. 
3. Using an immersion blender or food processor, blend together soaked cashews, cashew soaking liquid, cilantro, jalapenos, garlic, miso, lime juice, and salt (to taste) until smooth.
4. Serve with eggs, as a dipping sauce, or alongside your protein of choice.

#peruvianfood #hotsaucelover #sauces #condiments

🥞🫦🥞Did you know you could use your (dutch baby) pancake as a plate— it’s like a 10-in-1 (RECIPE BELOW)

As a lover of pancakes and a hater of waffles, the dutch baby pancake is the new supreme. Kinda like @ourplace’s upgrade “Always Pan 2.0” with stronger nonstick and a pan that you can chuck in the oven faster than a double text 📸 

I’m so excited they gave us a pan that truly does it all (especially for the small kitchen girlies) #ourplacepartner

Here’s how to make the dutch baby in your new pan:
- 3 large eggs, at room temperature
- ½c ap flour
- ½c oat milk, at room temperature
- 1 tbsp sugar
- 1 tbsp ras el hangout or curry powder
- 1/4c unsalted butter
- Toppings: 
- Harissa Carrot Salad (1 tbsp harissa, juice of 1 lemon, pinch of salt)
- Zesty Snap Peas (1 tbsp olive oil, 8oz snap peas, zest of 1 lemon)
Process
* Preheat oven to 425F and move rack to center of oven. 
* Make your toppings. (Harissa Carrot Slaw) Peel the carrots into ribbons using a peeler. Toss with harissa, lemon juice, and a pinch of salt. Set aside. (Zesty Snap Peas) Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a pan over medium heat. Add snap peas with zest of 1 lemon and a pinch of salt. Toss the peas for 3 to 4 mins until slightly seared and bright green. Remove fro heat and set aside. 
* Wipe the pan clean and place it into the oven for 5 mins to heat. While the pan heats, whisk together eggs, flour milk, sugar, ras el hangout, and sugar until combined and smooth. You can also blend it.
* Remove pan and add butter to your Always Pan 2.0 (or 10-inch skillet) to melt. Pour batter into pan and place in the oven for 20 to 25 mins until the pancake has puffed up and is golden. 
* Remove from oven and serve with favorite toppings (harissa carrot slaw, sprouts, seared snap peas, seared mushrooms, labneh, aleppo pepper, drizzle of olive oil)

🇲🇦 Moroccan Plant-Based Kofta doubles as a meal and as a snack, like you! (RECIPE BELOW) ⬇️ 

My childhood was sponsored by these oval-shaped “burgers” that my mom would make once a week when grilling season was in its prime. It was the kind of meal that was so easy to make and even EASIER to share.

Hence why every kid and their mother on the block waited for some every weekend. But with it came the opportunity to share a meal, and the companionship that comes with it, with our loved ones and strangers alike— building a more tight-knit community. It tastes like home and I hope it does for you too <3

Here’s how you can make and share this with your loved ones: Moroccan Kofta
- 1lb @ikeausa plant-based mince (or vegan meat of choice)
- 1/4 cup chopped parsley
- 1/4 red onion, diced
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1 tsp cumin
- 1/4 tsp salt
Izzy’s Cuke Salad 
- 4 Persian cucumbers, diced
- 1 pint grape tomatoes, halved
- 1/4 red onion, diced
- 2 tbsp finely chopped cilantro
- Juice of 1 lime
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1/2 tsp sumac
- Salt/pepper to taste
Process:
1. Season the kefta by adding the parsley, onion, olive oil, cumin, salt/pepper to the meat. Using your hands, bring everything together until incorporated. 
2. To form kofta, take 2 heaping tbsp’s of the mixture and roll into a ball. Gently press into the palm of your hand to form a disc. Roll one end towards the other, forming a shape similar to a cigar. Pinch the ends closed.
3. On a grill or grill pan, grill the meat on medium heat until cooked through, about 3 to 4 mins per side.
4. To make the cucumber salad, dice your cucumbers (I like to peel some of the skin gently, leaving some remaining), dice your onions, chop your herbs, and roll your limes to get the juices flowing. In a bowl, mix all of the ingredients together until combined. Taste and adjust seasoning, adding more salt if needed, more olive oil if it’s lacking “depth”, or more lime juice if it needs more “brightness”.
5. Serve with saffron basmati rice or snack on them w/ your fingy’s

#moroccanfood #kefta #easydinners #plantbasedrecipes

MISO- BROWN BUTTER ZUCCHINI BREAD for the girlies who forget to eat their veggies but won’t forget to send a txt (Recipe Below)

As a 20-something, I’m shook that I still forget to eat vegetables for days at a time... so if you’re slacking like I am, there ain’t never a reason to not get you vitamin fix through a pastry that also makes you feel as good as you look.

This loaf is moist and bouncy, sweet yet savory, and perfect for a cute picnic or mid-day snack (like you) 

Here’s how to make it:
12-ounce zucchini (pre-squeeze)
1 3/4c all-purpose flour
1 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp baking soda
1 tsp cinnamon
1/2 tsp cardamom
1/2 tsp nutmeg
1/2c brown sugar
1/2c white sugar
2 eggs
1/2 c olive oil
1/4 cup yogurt
1/4 cup salted butter
1 tbsp white miso
(Process)
1. In a saucepot, heat the butter over medium-low heat until melted. Stir and cook the butter until slightly golden and the milk solids in the butter begin to brown. Whisk in the miso until incorporated. Remove from heat and set aside.
2. In a big bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda/powder, cinnamon, cardamom, and nutmeg until combined. Set aside.
3. Shred the zucchini, skin included. Using a cheesecloth or thin kitchen towel, wring out as much moisture as possible and set aside. In a medium bowl, mix together the eggs, olive oil, white sugar, brown sugar, yogurt, and miso-brown butter until combined, about 2 minutes. Stir in the shredded zucchini.
4. Pour the wet batter into the dry. Using a spatula, fold the ingredients together until just combined. Grease a 9x3 loaf pan with butter and line it with parchment paper. Pour the batter into the pan and set aside.
5. To make frizzled onions, thinly slice 1/2 an onion, vertically. Heat 1/4 cup olive oil in a shallow pan over medium-low heat. Cook onions, stirring frequently, until slightly golden brown. Remove and blot with a paper towel to remove oil. Sprinkle onions on top of the batter.
6. Bake the loaf at 350F in the center rack of the oven for 60-70 mins or until a toothpick comes out clean when inserted in the center. Cover the loaf with aluminum foil 25 minutes in.
7. Serve with butter and flaky salt.

#zucchini #zucchinibread #bakingfromscratch

I need y’all to be as obsessed with Tfaya (Moroccan Caramelized Onions and Raisins) as I am via Whipped Feta (RECIPE BELOW) 🇲🇦

Now that it is PRIME sun out, cheeks out szn 🫦🍑, having a lineup of dips for picnics, beach days, and parties that go feral until the early morning is NON-NEGOTIABLE

This whipped feta dip is zesty, tangy, bright, and slightly sweet thanks to the sweet and savory Tfaya placed on top. I love serving this with my favorite vessel, @simplemills Almond Flour crackers 🌼 which are the perfect bite-sized blend of almond, sunflower seed, and flax seed flour— iconic cracker to pair with a scrumptious dip #simplemillspartner

Here’s how to make it:

(Tfaya)
1-lb yellow onions
1/4 cup unsalted butter
hefty pinch of kosher salt
1/2 tsp cinnamon
 
1/4 tsp ginger
pinch of saffron threads *(about 2 to 3)*
1/4 cup raisins, *soaked in hot water for 20 to 30 minutes*
1 tbsp sugar
1/2 tbsp orange blossom water*
(Whipped Feta Dip)
8oz feta
1/4 cup labneh or full-fat greek yogurt
zest of 1 lemon
1/2 tsp sumac
1/2 preserved lemon, minced
1 garlic clove, minced
1 tbsp granulated sugar 

Process:

1. To make the tfaya: Soak your raisins in hot water for 20-30 mins, then set aside. Cut your onions by slicing them in half and then vertically from the root to the center. Heat the butter over medium-low heat. Saute onions with a pinch of kosher salt for about 25 mins, stirring consistently. Once they begin to become golden, add the spices, raisins (drained), orange blossom water, and sugar. Continue cooking for another 20 mins until it reaches an auburn color. Store in an airtight container. Bring to room temp prior to using in the future.
2. To make the Whipped Feta: In a food processor, blend together the feta, labneh, lemon zest, sumac, preserved lemon, garlic, and sugar. Whip until smooth and combined. Taste and add more salt/sumac to taste.
3. Plate the whipped feta dip on a plate. Garnish with the tfaya, a drizzle of olive oil, chopped parsley.
4. Serve with @simplemills Almond Flour Crackers, crudite, and more!

Seared mushrooms in a zesty marinade is going to be THE personality trait this summer 😌 (recipe below)

This pollo a la brasa inspired marinade takes queues from the classic Peruvian dish. 🇵🇪 Full of citrus notes from lime, warming spices like cayenne and cumin, and the perfect amount of saltiness from soy sauce.

This dish, and marinade, is the perfect example of how beautifully cultures can merge, bringing with it new and innovative meals, traditions, and community. ✨Here’s how to make it ✨
- Juice of 2 limes
- zest of 1 lime
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1 tbsp miso paste
- 1 tbsp dark soy sauce
- 1 tbsp Dijon mustard
- 1 tbsp maple syrup
- 1 garlic clove, minced
- 1/2 tsp cayenne
- 1 tsp ground cumin
- salt, to taste

Directions:

2. Peel apart your oyster mushrooms into chicken nugget bite pieces. Marinate them in a bowl for about 5 to 10 minutes.
3. Heat 2 tbsp high smoke point oil (like avocado oil) in a cast iron skillet over medium heat
4. Sear the oyster mushrooms on both sides until golden brown and slightly crispy on both sides
5. Serve with rice, aji verde, and fresh cilantro
6. Dive in!
