Sweet and savory pasta! Veggies! Dates! Fun Pasta Shapes Only!

This pasta follows my formula of a “pantry” pasta and even though this uses fresh produce, you can add any frozen/canned veggies your heart or pocket desires. 

Here’s how to make it:
1-pint cherry tomatoes
3 tablespoons olive oil
4 garlic cloves
1/2 bunch asparagus, sliced in half cut diagonally 
1/4 tsp cumin
1/4 tsp aleppo pepper
4oz pasta
1/4 cup pasta cooking liquid
1/3 cup grated Parmigiano reggiano
4 dates, chopped 
zest of 2 lemons 
juice of 1 lemon
20 mint leaves, chiffonaded 
2 tablespoons parsley

process:
1. Bring a pot of water with 1 tbsp kosher salt to a boil. Add pasta and cook until al dente. 
2. While pasta cooks, in a skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add whole cherry tomatoes and saute for 3-4 mins until blistered. Add garlic and saute until fragrant, about 1 min.
3. Add asparagus (could also add peas, leeks, etc). Saute until asparagus is vibrant. Add cumin and aleppo pepper and saute until fragrant, about 1 min. 
4. At this point pasta should be done. With a slotted spoon, transfer pasta into the pan with the veggies along with about 1/4 cup of pasta cooking liquid. Add cheese and chopped dates—carefully toss to bring everything together over medium heat. The dates should “melt” into the pasta, making a glossy sauce. 
5. Add lemon juice/zest and mint/parsley (save some on the side to garnish, about 1 tbsp each). Toss everything together until combined. Taste and season with more salt/pepper or aleppo pepper.
6. Plate and garnish with more cheese, fresh herbs, a drizzle of olive oil, and some sumac. 

#veggiepasta #vegandinnerideas #cookingvideos

This barbie is putting rhubarb jam on everything 🦩🦩🦩 especially coconut lime pancakes (recipe below)

Now… we’ve entered rhubarb season where the girls are inclined to wake up at sunrise to sprint to the farmers market to put a down payment on this sour veggie

it’s often used in many desserts (think crumbles and pies), especially when paired with strawberries but can work beautifully as a compote/jam as well! it’s more versatile— use it with pancakes, on oatmeal, savory toast. it’s barbie’s world and anything is possible

here’s how to make rhubarb jam:
1lb rhubarb
1c granulated sugar
zest of 1 lime
1/4 cup lime juice
1/2 fennel bulb, diced
6 cardamom pods
pinch of salt

process:
1. Chop rhubarb and dice fennel (remove the stem and the fronds). Add the rhubarb, fennel, sugar, lime zest/juice, and cardamom pods in a pot. Bring to a slight boil, stir then reduce to a simmer. Cover it slightly with a lid and stir every couple of minutes until the mixture reduces and thickens. After about 20 mins, add the salt and stir once more. 
2. Pour into a sterilized, airtight container and let sit on the counter until it comes to room temp then refrigerate. Serve w/ pancakes

I was skeptical, but lionsmane mushrooms really do be tasting like shrimp 🦐🦐🦐 make a po boy 🗣️ (recipe below)

Lionsmane is known for its health benefits and cognitive function but it’s texture and natural flavors resemble the juiciest shrimp when deep fried (the best preparation)

Now Po’ Boys (Poor Mans Sandwich) originated in NOLA during the streetcar strike, where these sandwiches were given to strikers for free by two previous street car conductors who were then restaurant owners. 

This sandwich speaks on the incredible resiliency communities of color have leaned on for centuries, using the means they have access to create something beautiful and delicious- while showing up for their community simultaneously.

This version is my twist on it, bringing some Moroccan flair that I’m sure my dad would’ve down if he tried to do so as well. Here’s how:

“Shrimp” 
-1/2 cup all-purpose flour
-1/2 cup coarse semolina flour
-1 tbsp ras el hanout
-1/2 tsp kosher salt
-3/4 cups oat milk
-1 tbsp golden flax meal
-1 tbsp harissa paste
-16-oz lionsmane mushroom
Vegetable oil, for frying

Maple Harissa Carrot Slaw
-1/4c yogurt
-2 tbsp tahini
-2 tbsp harissa
-1 tbsp maple syrup
-Juice of 1 lemon
-pinch of cinnamon
-salt/pepper to taste
-3 to 4 large carrots, shredded
-20 mint leaves, chiffonaded

Process:
1. For Shrimp: Mix together flour, semolina, Ras El Hanout, and salt in a bowl. Set aside. Mix together milk, flax meal, harissa paste in a bowl and let sit for 5 mins. While it sits, shred the mushroom from the base to the head to create shrimp like shapes. Heat 2 cups of vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Dredge mushrooms through wet batter, then the dry, and fry until golden. Place on a paper lined plate and sprinkle with flakey salt.
3. For the Slaw: Mix together yogurt, tahini, maple syrup, lemon, cinnamon, salt/pepper to taste. Save 2 tbsp for dressing the sandwich and use the rest to dress the carrots. Once coated, add the cut mint and toss once more.
4. To prepare: Toast a hoagie (I used a pretzel bun) and slather on the reserved sauce. Place arugula, the slaw, and the “shrimp” on top. Garnish w/ pickled onions

#poboy #sandwiches #mushroomrecipes

💥ZESTY RAMP CREAM CHEESE! CUKES! SALSA MACHA! this has become my hyperfixation meal and there’s no sign of stopping! (recipe below)

now i’m surprised i was able to find ramps considering that they’re 1. an endangered species in the northeast (so please try to source them from folks who forage/harvest them responsibly) and 2. it has its foot on the necks of every bougie home cook in the tristate area 

they add a beautiful mild garlic flavor to any dish it’s added to. This ramp cream cheese uses a few ingredients because falling into simplicity is something i’m trying to find comfort in— everything doesn’t need a banillion ingredients, garnishes, or spices i fear! so the ramp is truly the star in this and we can devour it for all her glory and garlickyness

here’s how to make it:
8oz cream cheese
1 bundle of ramps
zest of 2 lemons 
1/2 tsp sugar 
salt, to taste

process: 
1. heat a pot of water over medium heat and bring to a simmer. prepare a large bowl with ice cold water and set aside. Remove the stems from the greens of the ramps. These stems have a lot of flavor so keep them!! I love to pickle them or add them to anything im sauteeing. Add the ramp greens to the simmering water and blanch them for about 1-2 mins until bright green. Immediately transfer to the ice cold water.
2. Using your hands or a cheesecloth, wring out as much water from the ramps and chop it. Set aside
3. zest your lemons and mix with the sugar to help enhance the aroma and oils of the lemon zest. add it to a food processor with the cream cheese, chopped ramos, and salt (about 1/4 tsp). blend until incorporated and the cream cheese is a light green.
4. serve on toast with cucumbers, mint, salsa macha, and lemon juice!

#toasttuesday #ramps #easybreakfastideas

A fritatta is underrated!! I made this 3x in 12 days and so should you 🤲🏼🫄

Fritatta’s are the chill girl we all wanna be. She ebbs and flows, is versatile, can be whipped up in an hour and feeds a crowd. It’s my meal prep of the summer and just you WAIT till those tomatoes start getting nice and juicy, cause they’ll end up in this too.

Here’s how to make it:

- 4 tbsp butter
- 1 shallot
- 3 garlic cloves
- 1 tsp aleppo pepper
- 1 tsp sumac
- 12 eggs
- 1/2 cup heavy cream
- 4oz feta, crumbled
- 20 mint leaves, chiffonaded
- 1/2 tsp kosher salt
- 8oz peas
Flour slurry
-1/2 cup water
-1 tbsp all-purpose flour

Process:

1. Preheat your oven to 400F and place the rack in the center. Boil your fresh or frozen peas until just cooked per the cooking instructions. Drain, dry, and set aside.
2.  Heat a 10-inch NONSTICK skillet over medium heat and melt 1 tbsp butter. Add the shallots and garlic— sauté until softened. Add sumac and Aleppo pepper and sauté for 1 min. Remove from pan and set aside.
3. Whisk together the eggs and milk until just combined. Don’t overmix and be gentle as we want as little air incorporated as possible so we can keep a custard-like texture. STIR in the shallots, mint, and crumbled feta. 
4. In the skillet, melt the 3 tbsp butter over medium-high heat. Add the peas and cook until slightly crispy. Whisk together the flour and water to make a slurry and then pour/distribute it evenly over the peas. Cook until the peas begin to set and stick together, about 2 mins. Pour the egg mixture slowly over the peas. Transfer to the oven and bake for 15-20 mins until the eggs are set.
5. Serve with garlicky yogurt, salsa macha, microgreens, and some fresh pepper for flair!

#fritatta #quickbreakfast #eggrecipes

An Upside Down Olive Oil Cake olive oil cake a day keeps a Gemini man away— and helps you use up some rhubarb (recipe below) 🤲🏼😋

Like any partner, olive oil cakes rely on quality (of the olive oil being used). We want Fresh! Delicious! Vibrant! Juicy! I have been a @getgraza stan since it’s inception last year— it’s quite literally perfect. As a taurus moon, I WILL invest in aesthetics with efficiency with their squeezy bottle, hehe— it’s balance and I’m unstable. If you’d like to try it for yourself (u should) use “LAHBCO” for $5 off the duo set and report back pls! #grazapartner

Now, go make this cake for your crush
- 1lb rhubarb
- 1 tbsp flour
-4 tbsp butter
-1/2c light brown sugar
- 2 cup all-purpose flour
- 1 tsp baking powder
- 1/2 tsp baking soda
- 1/2 tsp sea salt
- 3/4 cup granulated sugar
- zest of 1 lemon (about 1 tbsp)
- juice of 1 lemon (3 tbsp)
- 2 eggs or 1/4 cup apple sauce
- 1/2 cup @getgraza “Sizzle” Extra Virgin olive oil
- 1/2 cup oat milk (room temp), substitute with non-dairy milk of choice
- 1/2 teaspoon almond extract

Process:

1. Preheat oven to 350F and place a rack in the center of the oven. Grease a 9” springform pan and lay a piece of parchment paper on the bottom. 
2. Rinse rhubarb and chop it into 1 1/2” pieces. Toss with flour and arrange them in a 🌀 or just layer along the bottom of the pan. Set aside
3. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder/soda, and salt. Set aside
4. Zest 1 lemon and combine with the sugar using your fingers. Add the eggs and whisk until incorporated. Whisk in the milk, olive oil, almond extract, and lemon juice. 
5. Pour wet into dry and fold until incorporated. Fold in chopped tarragon once more. 
6. Melt butter & sugar over medium heat in a pot, stirring until smooth and combined. Pour over rhubarb in pan evenly. Pour the batter over the rhubarb. Bake for 30-35 mins or until a toothpick comes out clean when inserted. 
7. Let cool for 10 mins. Remove the side of the springform pan, flip, and remove the parchment paper. Serve with labneh, Graza “Drizzle”, and flaky salt

🍋Another week of me trying to make PRESERVED LEMONS the IT girl (recipe below)

🇲🇦Throughout the Maghreb community and the Middle East/North Africa- they’ve always been “in”! Preserved Lemons are used in so many different formats, and can be incorporated into so many dishes thanks to their versatile flavor and the brightening acidity that many meals are begging for 

In Morocco, preserved lemon is used for a variety of dishes, but famously for their preserved lemon & olive chicken tagine. My fondest memory of using these tangy citrus and their sappy juices are of my grandmother finely mincing every bit to add to her tagine for dinner. The result you ask? The perfect amount of tang, acidity, brightness, and ✨funk✨ with every bite 🫦

Here’s how you make it:
*4 to 6 small lemons (for a 16oz jar)
*about 1/2 cup coarse kosher salt
*juice from 2 lemons (about 1/3 cup)
Directions:
1. Rinse your lemons well and grab a STERILIZED, CLEAN mason jar.
2. Slice the lemons in half in one direction and then in half again in the other, creating four segments but leaving one side intact intact on one side.
3. Add about 2 tbsp of salt to the bottom of the jar. Pour salt into the center of each lemon, separating the quarters of the lemons to ensure salt gets into every nook and cranny
3. Add the lemon to the jar, cover with more salt, and repeat the process. Slightly squeeze the lemons in the jar after adding each one. 
4. Cover with a tight lid and leave in a cool, dark place for 4 to 6 weeks. DO NOT OPEN THE JAR!
5. After 4 to 6 weeks, you should be left with fermented, sappy, softened lemons and their juices to use in salad dressings, pasta, tagines, or even dessert

🫶🏻

#preservedlemon #moroccanfood #easyrecipes #pickling #lemons

Mint chip 🤝 best ice cream flavor of all time, PERIOD! Here’s how you can make it vegan w/o an ice cream maker (recipe below)

Now you must know, my fav mint “chip” hack is using cookies instead of chips, specifically @simplemills Cocoa Cashew Creme Nut Butter Stuffed Sandwich Cookies that’re SO perfectly crunchy and sweetened w/ organic coconut sugar — plus they’re made w/ buckwheat flour which is a legendary cover crop used by farmers to help protect the soil & feed the bee (hive) 🐝🤭 #simplemillspartner

Adding ‘em to this gives “cookies and (mint) cream” vibes for an iconic summer treat— inspired by the BEST mint chip ice cream in NYC from @mikeylikesit. We blend spearmint leaves w/ coconut cream for herby, freshness that could be enhanced w/ some peppermint extract if toothpaste is the vibe you’re going for. It’s perfect 🦖

Here’s how to make it:
-(2) 14oz can of coconut cream
-12 spearmint stems (about 30 leaves)
-3/4 cup white granulated sugar
-1/2 tsp kosher salt
-1/4 tsp mint extract, optional
-2 tbsp vodk*/tequil*
-1 box of @simplemills Cocoa Cashew Creme Nut Butter Stuffed Sandwich Cookies

Process:
-In a blender, combine 1 can of coconut cream with mint leaves, sugar, and salt until frothy, about 2 mins. Pour through a fine mesh sieve; remove the mint leaves. Pour back into the blender with the other can of coconut cream, mint extract, and vodka. Blend until frothy once more
-Pour into a 9x3 loaf pan. Cover w/ plastic wrap, ensuring it touches the surface of the cream. Freeze for 3 hours. Using a spoon stir the cream once. Crush the @simplemills nut-butter stuffed cookies and stir them into the cream. Cover w/ plastic wrap and freeze overnight. 
-Serve w/ chocolate ganache, flaky salt, and 1 @simplemils Cocoa Cashew Creme Nut Butter Stuffed Sandwich Cookie

#icecream #mintchip #vegandessert #dessertlover

The only potato salad I want at the cookout has no mayo… but it’s tangy and sexy like u (recipe below) 🥔🥔🥔

I saw a video about never keeping a nice thought to yourself and the same holds true for a fire recipe. This potato salad is community solidarity as much as making it for your chosen family is. 

It’s tangy, zesty, and a little smokey that blossoms with hints of salsa macha in the dressing. 

Salsa mocha originates from Mexico’s states of Veracruz and Oaxaca. Its dried chiles and garlic are reminiscent to the chili oil’s found throughout Southeast Asia and china! It’s quite literally THE PERFECT CONDIMENT. I love to get mine from @forallthingsgoodbk here in BKLYN, btw 

Also I promise you don’t need the mayonnaise, put 🗣️ the 🗣️ mayo 🗣️ down!

🔥Here’s how to make it🔥
* 1lb teeny tiny potatoes
* 2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
* 2 tbsp red wine vinegar
* zest & juice or 1 lime
* 1 tbsp dijon mustard
* 1/2 tsp cumin
* 1-2 tbsp salsa macha
* 2 Persian cucumbers, diced
* 1/3 preserved lemon, diced
* 1/3 cup chopped dill
* 1/3 cup chopped scallions
* 1/2 red onion, diced
*2 radishes, thinly sliced
* pomegrante molasses, for garnish
Directions:
1. Boil the potatoes in HEAVILY salted water (this helps season the potatoes from within, like pasta!) While they cook, prep the veggies and soak the radishes and red onions in ice-cold water.
2. Drain the potatoes once fork tender. Whisk together the olive oil, vinegar, dijon mustard, salsa mocha, and cumin in a bowl. Set aside.
3. In a large bowl, toss the potatoes with the dressing. I like to use a fork to help break up the potatoes slightly for more rugged edges.
4. Add the cucumbers, herbs, radishes & red onion. Toss.
5. Garnish with a drizzle of pomegranate molasses and dive in

If your lemon bar doesn’t have preserved lemon, I don’t want it! But these do 🍋👅🍋

Lemon bars are highly underrated, unlike Gemini men. These use preserved lemon paste for salty, umami layers with every bite. It’s like sunshine & chaos!

With vegan desserts, you need quality ingredients that help balance most substitutions. I swear by @gardenoflife’s coconut oil and golden flax meal for most vegan desserts for extra depth of flavor and some added health benefits. I love them <3 and if you want to try them out, use “LAHBCO20” for 20% off ANY purchase! #golpartner 🥹

Crust
1 1/2 cup rolled oats
1 cup raw cashews
1/4 tsp sea salt
1/4 cup honey 
2 tbsp sugar
2 tbsp @gardenoflife Golden Milled Flaxseed
4 tbsp @gardenoflife Raw Extra Virgin Coconut Oil(melted)
1 1/2 tbsp orange blossom water

Preserved Lemon Filling
1/4 cup preserved lemon paste (sub lemon juice)
zest of 3 lemons
3 tbsp lemon juice
1 1/2 cups granulated sugar
1-1/4 cups canned full-fat coconut milk
6 tbsp cornstarch
heaping 1/8 to 1/4 tsp turmeric, for color

Directions
1. Preheat oven to 350F.
2. Make crust: In a food processor, pulse together the oats, cashews, and sugar until almost fine. Add coconut oil, honey, sugar, and orange blossom water. You’re looking for a shortbread cookie dough kind of consistency. Line a greased 8x8 baking tray with parchment paper. Press the dough along the bottom evenly and place in the freezer to set.
3. Make filling: In a bowl, combine sugar and lemon zest with your hands until fragrant. Whisk in cornstarch until combined. Then whisk in the preserved lemon paste and lemon juice until smooth. Lastly, whisk in the coconut milk and turmeric (for color) until smooth. Pour into a skillet, bring to a simmer over med heat while continuously stirring, until it begins to bubble and thicken. 
4. Once thickened (similar to a curd or pastry cream), pour it over the crust. Bake for 20 minutes.
5. Bring to room temp and then cover it with plastic wrap, ensuring it touches the surface of the curd. Chill overnight or for at least 6 hours.
6. Prior to serving, wet a sharp knife and cut bars into 9 servings. Dust w/ powdered sugar.

#lemonbars #summerdesserts #easyrecipesathome

🤨🫰🏽 Brown Butter-Orange Gochujang pasta sounds so wrong BUT! IT! IS! SO! RIGHT! (recipe below!)

 i had a fever dream about this and even though I felt absolutely delulu making it, everything is clearer now. This is inspired by @ericjoonho’s “Gochujang Butter Noodles” which are so perfect to whip up before you go feral this weekend, or at 2 am when you stumble home like the rat you are (kidding 🤭🐀)

The sweet, savory, and spicy flavors of gochujang are balanced SO WELL by bright notes of acidity that pack a punch with every bite. It’s like a lil sunburn after you baked in the sun all day and took your post-beach shower.

Here’s how to make it
6 tbsp unsalted butter
1 shallot, minced
4 garlic cloves, minced
2-inches ginger, minced
6 oz shittake mushrooms, diced
1/2 tsp cumin
2 tbsp @milkimchi Gochujang Concentrated Paste 
1 tbsp soy sauce
juice and zest of 2 juicing oranges
1/2 cup full-fat oatmilk or canned coconut milk, sub heavy cream
1/3 to 1/2 cup reserved pasta cooking liquid
4-6 oz bucatini pasta
1/4 cup shredded parmigiano reggiano, more for garnish
chives, for garnish
gochugaru, for garnish optional
Process:
1. Cut your shallots/garlic/mushrooms and mince your ginger. Bring a pot of water to a boil and salt it heavily (about 1/2 tbsp per 4 cups water used).
2. Brown 4 tbsp butter over medium-low heat in a skillet, about 5-6 mins. Add shallots, garlic, ginger, and mushrooms and saute until softened, about 3 to 4 mins.
3. Add bucatini to boiling water and cook until al dente, about 8-10 mins or according to package instructions.
4. To the sauce, stir in the cumin, gochujang, soy sauce, orange zest/juice and cook briefly until combined. Pour in oat milk and stir until fully incorporated. Bring to a simmer and let it reduce by half.
5. Add drained, cooked pasta with 1/4 cup pasta water (to start) and parmigiano reggiano. Toss to coat and keep tossing until the sauce is emulsified and glossy. Add more pasta water if needed. Add salt if needed.
6. Plate and garnish pasta with more shredded cheese and chives.

#gochujang #pastaaddict #easydinners #brownbutter #pastarecipes

🗣️ Cold Soup matters—It’s refreshing, it’s sexy, it’s elevated. Put respect on it’s name 🫰🏽RECIPE BELOW)

I’ve had the privilege of experiencing cold soups throughout my life thanks to my chosen family. 😌 Borsht from Rusty’s Ukranian mother, Natasha. Tarator from my father’s middle eastern friends. Gazpacho from my dad’s co-workers. It tastes like the sound of an ice-cold can of iced tea being opened.

This version is inspired by Abdoogh Khiar, a Persian yogurt soup that’s full of herbaceous notes from dill and mint, romantic, floral aromas thanks to the rose water, and some electrolytes from everyone’s most mid-veggie, cucumbers. I couldn’t help but get this out of my head when I was served it recently, so here’s my take :’)

(Marinated Beans)
1 15-oz can of beans (cannellini or white)
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp sesame oil
1 tbsp rice vinegar
2 tbsp dill
1 tsp aleppo pepper (sub w/ 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes)
1/2 tsp za’atar
salt, to taste
(Soup)
2lb cucumbers, deseeded
2 cups of cooked peas 
1/3 cup water, to thin
1 can full-fat coconut milk (I like the Chaoko brand)
1/4 cup chopped mint
1/4 cup chopped dill
juice of 2 lemons
1 tsp rose water
salt/pepper, to taste

Process:

1. In a bowl, whisk together the oils, dill, aleppo pepper and za’atar. Add drained beans and rice vinegar, then toss to coat. Season w/ salt and pepper, to taste. Cover and marinate overnight (or place in freezer for 30 mins)
2. Make Soup: Cook your peas and blanch them in ice-cold water, then drain. Deseed your cucumbers by slicing them in half and running a small spoon down the center. Roughly chop and add to a HIGH-SPEED blender with the peas, coconut milk, and water. Blend until smooth. Add the dill, mint, lemons, and rose water, blend again until combined and a beautiful light green hue has come to fruition. 
3.  Season w/ salt/pepper and blend once more. You can pass the soup through a sieve for a smoother consistency or keep it more rustic in texture. Place in a tupperware and chill until cool.
4. Serve in a bowl or glass w/ marinated beans garnished on top. Garnish w/ olive oil aleppo pepper and fresh cracked pepper.

#coldsoup #summerrecipes #easyveganrecipes #healthysnacks

🌮I will be serving these picadillo-potato tacos at every picnic and bbq this summer, wigs included (RECIPE BELOW)

I am so grateful to be working with @ikeausa this pride to cook up ways we can take up, and create, safe space for our chosen families of all kinds to feel loved, nourished, fed so they can be the baddies they were meant to be.

Picadillo is one of the most versatile ingredients I grew up eating. It’s affordable, feeds a crowd, and tastes DELECTABLE. It’s what my mom made for me, my brother, and the neighborhood kids, who she treated like family, when they visited our house. 

Y’all know I’m a STAN for @ikeausa vegan options, but I also love them as a company. They lead such an incredible example of how companies can show up for their queer and marginalized employees by providing life-affirming care and working conditions 🏳️‍⚧️🥹

🏳️‍🌈 This June, 100% of every sale of their iconic STORSTOMMA rainbow shopping bags will be donated to True Colors United (an organization supporting our LGBTQIA+ youth). So go pick up some vegan meat, lingonberry syrup, a rainbow bag and make some food with your chosen family  #IKEApartner #myIKEAUSA #IKEAPride #TakeUpSpace

Here’s how to make the picadillo:
16-oz @ikeausa VÄRLDSKLOK vegan meat
2 tbsp olive oil
1 green bell pepper, diced
1 carrot, diced
1/2 yellow onion, diced
4 garlic cloves, minced
3 tbsp sofrito
3 tbsp tomato paste
1/2 tsp cumin
1/4 tsp oregano
1/4 tsp pepper
1/2 tsp salt, to taste

Process:
1.Heat olive oil n a large skillet over med heat. Sauté the garlic and onions until fragrant (about 1-2 minutes). 
2.Add the bell pepper and carrot, saute until softened (about 3-4 mins).
3.Add the sofrito, tomato paste, cumin, oregano, salt, and pepper. Saute for 2 mins
4.Add the vegan meat and toss to coat. Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, for 5-10 minutes until fragrant. Adjust any seasonings per your taste.
5.Serve it on top of potato pancakes or corn tostada/tortillas with a cilantro yogurt sauce, pickled onions, cotija cheese,and hot sauce

#puertoricanfood

Day 2 of me trying to convince you to make cold soup 🤾🧊

At first this was inspired by Naengmyeon, a Korean cold noodle soup traditionally served with buckwheat noodles in a chilled broth. But with feedback, it more closely resembles Kong-guksu, a korean dish of cold noodles in a creamy soy milk broth!! You should absolutely check out @cafemaddy who has recipes for more authentic versions of both dishes, and go make them as I will!♥️🤲🏼

The coconut-nut butter broth may not be traditional, but it’s such a lovely base that lets any cooling garnishes you have really shine, like cucumber and a soft boiled egg usually served with Kong-Guksu

Here’s how to make it ~Broth
1 15oz can full-fat coconut milk
2 tbsp sunflower seed butter 
1 tbsp gochujang PASTE
1 tbsp white miso paste
2 garlic cloves
Juice/zest of 2 limes
1 tbsp sugar
Salt, to taste
4-6 ice cubes
~Assembly
2oz Buckwheat noodles
Soft boiled egg
Cucumber ribbons
Shredded cabbage
Cilantro/scallions
Radishes

Process:
1. To make the broth, blend together all of the broth ingredients except the ice. Once combined, taste and adjust the seasoning if needed. Then blend in ice and chill in the freezer
2. Boil your noodles, remove from water, and place in an ice bath. In the same water, boil your egg in boiling water for 7 mins and place in the same ice bath. 
3. Shred, peel, and chop your garnishes and set aside. Assemble your noodles in a shallow bowl. Pour about 1/3 of the broth around the noodles and garnish with your favorite cooling ingredients.
4. Add chili oil for a lil kick and sesame seeds for crunch

#coldsoup #summerrecipes #noodles #lunchideas #gochujang

Ginger-Turmeric Tonic is the ONLY thing I shall be crawling for in this heat, thank you v much 🤲🏼☀️🌱 (recipe below)

With summer comes swamp ass which has a direct correlation to decision making, hence the reason you’re waking up with a hang0ver rn! 

This drink is perfect to boost some antioxidants and anti-inflammatory goodness into your body! Coconut water can be added for electrolytes or your favorite b00ze of hair of the dog is more your style 🫄 woof 

here’s how to make it:
4-inch ginger
2 cups water
juice and zest of 4 lemons
20 mint leaves
1/2 tsp turmeric
hefty pinch of black pepper
1/4 cup honey
1/2 cup unsweetened iced tea or coconut water
splash of gin (Optional)
 
Process:
1. Slice ginger thinly, zest lemons and juice them. Add ginger, lemon zest, juice, and mint leaves into a pot. Bring to a simmer over medium-low heat and cook for 10 mins. Let cool and whisk in honey.
2. Strain ginger mixture into a bottle and mix with turmeric and black pepper. Chill until cold.
3. When serving, shake before serving over ice. Fill the glass halfway and then top with iced tea or coconut water 

 #icedtea #mocktails #summerdrinks #turmeric

Spicy Caesar Salad Pizza 🤝 fuq a cheese slice when you can have garlic bread and lettuc, yk? (RECIPE BELOW)

Bliss as a child was a watered down fruit punch and a caesar salad slice from “Orignals Pizzaeria”. But now we make it at home, here’s how!

(Dressing)
* 1/4 cup tahini
* 2 tbsp shredded vegan parm
* 2 tbsp olive oil
* 2 tbsp cashew yogurt
* Juice and zest from 1 lemon 
* 2 clove garlic, grated or finely minced
* 1 tbsp harissa (sub Calabrian Chile paste)
* 1/2 tsp cumin
* 1-3 tablespoons warm water, to thin out dressing a bit to your liking
* Freshly ground salt and black pepper, to taste.
(Salad)
Pizza crust, of choice
3 tbsp salted butter
4 garlic cloves minced
Iceberg and romaine lettuce
Blackened tempeh or protein of choice
Process:
1. In a blender or immersion blender, combine all the ingredients until combined. Add salt/pepper to taste. Chill in the fridge.
2. Clean, rinse, and cut romaine lettuce. Please in an iceboat for 1 min and pat dry.
3. Cook pizza dough on the grill, in the stove, or on a large 12” greased skillet over med. heat until cooked through. While pizza cooks, mix together the softened butter with minced garlic until combined. Once golden, spread butter over one side of the pizza dough and cook for an additional minute. 
4. Toss salad w/ dressing and protein. Place on top of pizza and garnish w/ more cheese and breadcrumbs.

#caesarsalad #tahini #pizzarecipe #summerdinner #easydinnerideas

tbh all i ever want are dips for dinner. all of them, especially this whipped feta and pea one (recipe below)

They’re the perfect vessel for everything and my favorite way to use the seasons freshest produce! honestly, Oliver putnam from “Only m*rders in the building” spoke volumes when he said “You know, this is all I eat — dips for dinner,” he says. “I bet I have not had a regular entree for years”

dips are also the perfect vessel to run your fav crackers into. @simplemills is famous for just about every product but their veggie pita crackers are iconic, made with veggies as the main ingredients which just means i can get 1/3 serving of veggies per serving just by simply snacking (easy to demolish tbh) #simplemillspartner

here’s how to make it:
10oz frozen peas
1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil
juice and zestof 1 lemon
1 jalapeno, optional
1/4 cup chopped dill
3-4 garlic cloves, minced
4 oz feta
1/4 tsp cardamom
salt/pepper, to taste
@simplemills veggie pita crackers

Process:
1. Cook your frozen/fresh peas according to packaged instructions. Once cooked, transfer to an ice bath then drain.
2. If using a gas stove, carefully place jalapenos on the stove grate over medium heat, charring them on all sides. If using an electric stove, you can roast the jalapeno w/ a drizzle of olive oil in a 400F oven for 5 to 10 mins. Immediately transfer to a bowl with a lid and cover for 5 mins. This will create condensation that will help make it easier to remove the charred skin. Cut the stem off and chop the jalapeno. Set to the side
3. In a food processor, blend together the peas, lemon juice/zest, garlic and olive oil until combined and mostly smooth. Add the jalapeno, dill, feta, cardamom, and salt/pepper to taste. Blend until smooth and combined.
4. Garnish w/ cashew yogurt, olive oil, vegan caviar, flaky salt, and some aleppo pepper.

#peas #whippedfeta #appetizers #summerrecipes

if you won’t even try cold soup, GROW! UP! Make ajo blanco 🤾🤾🤾 (recipe below)

At this point, getting y’all to love soup in the summer just stems from my grandmothers obsession with it in the summer heat. But I won’t steer you astray with hot liquids in 87% humidity

Cold soup is fun! You can play with flavors! It’s refreshing, sexy, nourishing— unlike that man you keep giving second chances to.

Here’s how to make it:
1 cup (8oz) blanched almonds
3 cups water
1 garlic cloves
8oz crustless white/sourdough bread, cubed
1/2 tbsp rice vinegar
1 tbsp white miso
2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
salt, to taste
Process:
1. Bring a pot of water to boil and add your almonds. Let them boil for 1 minute, remove from water and transfer to an ice bath. Let sit for 1 minute. Remove the skins of the almond by gently squeezing one end of the almond in the palm of your hand. The nut should slip out.
2. To a high speed blender, add the almonds, water and garlic. Blend until frothy and smooth. Add the crustless bread and blend until smooth, about 2 mins.
3. Add the rice vinegar, miso, olive oil, and salt. Blend once more until combined and transfer to a container to chill.
4. To make the cabbage, whisk the olive oil, gochujang, maple syrup, and salt together. Cut the cabbage into wedges and brush the sauce onto one side. Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Press the cabbage w/ the sauce into the pan and brush the other side with the sauce. Cover and sear for about 2-3 mins per side, until golden. Keep brushing the cabbage with the sauce, carefully flipping it with 2 forks.
5. Serve w/ sweet and spicy seared cabbage, olive oil, tarragon, and aleppo pepper.

#coldsoup #ajoblanco #veganrecipe #summerrecipes #almonds

my new favorite summer lunch has unlocked—🌱🐢🥒Aguachile 🤝 Beans (recipe below)

Aguachile is a traditional Mexican dish (more specifically from the Mexican coastal state, Sinaloa). It originally was used to tenderize and season meat but evolved into adding such bright and zesty notes to shellfish captured along the coasts of Sinaloa.

Aguachile is one of my favorite things to devour in the summer cause it’s cooling (my window AC wishes she could). By no means is this traditional, but adding beans instead of fish just makes this even more accessible without losing the flavor. 

Here’s how to make it:
(Marinade)
* 1/2 cup lime juice 
* 3 cloves garlic chopped
* 1/2 cup fresh cilantro
* 1/4 cup fresh tarragon (optional, not traditional)
* 1 large jalapeno pepper chopped
* 1 cucumber, peeled, deseeded & chopped
* 1/2 tbsp sugar
* Salt to taste
*1-2 cans of beans
*red onion, radishes, cilantro (to garnish)

1. Add the lime juice, garlic, cilantro/tarragon, jalapeno, cucumber, sugar, and salt (to taste) to a blender and blitz until combined. Taste and adjust seasoning.
2. Drain a can of white beans and toss with the aguachile marinade until coated. Pour into a container and let it marinate overnight or for up to 3 days. 
3. Before serving, soak thinly sliced red onion & radiahes in ice cold water for 2 mins. Drain and garnish. Serve w/ toasted bread.

#aguachile #summerlunch #easylunchideas #latinamericanfood

gazpacho is like liquid iv and V8 had a baby— and if you can’t handle cold soup, stay parched 🥰 (RECIPE BELOW)

this is a sweet & spicy version of gazpacho. i’m talking seared peaches! harissa! it’s very much dichotomy of flavors like the dichotomy of lived experiences in this “land of the free”

it is so so hard to celebrate a day where women, queer folk, black and brown people, and all m@rginalized communities are disproportionately affected by l@ws that h@teful p0liticians and elect*ed officials put in place. 

every country has its flaws, and i know there is immense privilege in calling this country home—but it’s also so flawed to claim the “land of the free” when women don’t have b0dily autonomy, queer people can be discrimin@ted against legally, and systemic r@cism continues to beat down black and brown people.

 there is a lot to celeberate, but there is also a lot of HARD conversations to be had which are just easier to stomach with gazpacho. so make this. and stay safe

here’s how to make it:
2lbs tomatoes
1lb peaches
3 tbsp salted butter
1 cucumber, peeled and chopped
1 large yellow onion, chopped
1 garlic clove, minced
1 1/2 tbsp harissa
4 tbsp olive oil
2 tbsp rice vinegar or juce of 1 lime
pepper/salt
process
1. Cut tomatoes into quarters and remove the core/seeds. Set aside.
2. Slice peaches into quarters and remove the seeds. Heat a grill skillet or grill over medium heat. Brush peaches w/ melted butter and grill on both sides until golden brown. Set aside.
3. Add tomatoes, cucumber, peaches, cucumber, onion, and garlic in a blender. Blend until smooth, about 4 minutes. Add harissa, olive oil, rice vinegar, and season w/ salt and pepper.
4. Chill until cool. Serve w finely diced cucumber, red onion, a grilled peach, and fresh basil.

#gazpacho #tomatoes #peaches #summerrecipes

elote (inspired) pasta is so delicious it’s dumb silly 🌽🤝🍝

this is probably my favorite recipe i’ve ever developed 3 years ago. it’s so simple to make and perfect to share with friends. and if you’re airbnb mommy, this comes together in 20 mins so you can stress about who’s taking out the trash instead 🤭
(Sauce)
1 cup corn kernels
1 cup canned full-fat coconut milk
3 tbsp nutritional yeast
1/2 tbsp chili powder
2 garlic cloves
1/4 teaspoon salt
(Assembly)
8oz pasta of choice
1/2 cup grape tomatoes, sliced
1 lime, zest, and juice
cotija cheese, for garnish
1/3 cup cilantro, for assembly and garnish
chili powder, for assembly and garnish

To make the sauce:
1.!Blend together  the corn kernels, coconut milk, nutritional yeast, chili powder, garlic cloves, and salt.
2. Taste and adjust the seasoning (salt and pepper) to your liking. Once combined, place in an airtight container and set aside.

To assemble:
3. Boil your favorite pasta in heavily salted water. I prefer to use a noodle-like Fusili that has enough crevices that sauce can nestle into (providing the utmost amount of flavor)!

4. As the pasta cooks, heat two tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet. Saute the 1/2 cup of grape tomatoes until they blister and begin to release their juices.

5. Once pasta is cooked, reserve about 1/4 cup of pasta water and drain. Add the pasta to the skillet, and add the entirety of the pasta sauce made. 

6. Add the reserved pasta water and stir consistently until incorporated, ensuring the sauce is emulsifying. 

7. During the last 2-3 minutes, add lime juice and zest, and about 1/4 cup chopped cilantro.

8. garnish with fresh cotija cheese, fresh lime zest, chopped cilantro, and a dash of chili powder.

#elote #pastarecipe #easydinnerideas #corn

bread salads are superior to anything else— need i say more? 🤾 (RECIPE BELOW)

I don’t think I have the ability to stop thinking about Dakos Salad from Kiki’s in NYC. And I refuse to wait on that line for a table 3x a week so we fuqk it and make it at home.

Here’s how:
* 1 pound ripe tomatoes, cut into 1 1/2-inch chunks
* 1/2 small red onion, diced
* 1/4 cup kalamata olives, sliced 
* 1 tbsp capers, roughly chopped
* 3 tbsp fresh oregano or parsley leaves, chopped
* 3 tbsp fresh basil, chopped
* 4 to 6 thick slices of rye or sourdough, cut into chunks and toasted
* 1/2 cup feta, crumbled
Dressing
* 1/4 cup olive oil
* Juice of 1 lemon
* 1/4 tsp cumin
* 1/3 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste
* Black pepper, to taste
Process:
1. In a large bowl, make the dressing by whisking together all of the ingredients until smooth. Set aside
2. Toast your bread or break apart stale bread. Chop tomatoes, diced red onion, and slice olives. Add the bread, tomatoes, red onion, olives, capers, and feta cheese to the dressing. Toss to coat.
3. Add the oregano, basil and toss to coat once more. Taste and add more salt/pepper if needed.
4. Serve alongside a protein or serve with some tinned fish

#saladsofinstagram #summerrecipes #breadlover #greekfood #feta

🍓🍰 I’m just trying to make nostalgic desserts before they discontinue them all… and my happiness (RECIPE BELOW)

When I found out they *almost* discontinued the ice cream that made me who I am today (sweet and fruity), I ran to make this and you should too

It’s even easier with @simplemills Honey Cinnamon Sweet Thins that give that classic shortcake flavor. I also love them because they’re made with a diverse flour blend of cashews, flax, sunflower, and watermelon seeds (for a light & crispy texture + naturally GF) ♥️

Here’s how to make it:
Crust:
* 12oz Simple Mills Honey Cinnamon Sweet Thins
* 6oz unsalted butter, melted
* 2 tbsp white miso, optional
 Crumble
* 8oz Simple Mills Honey Cinnamon Sweet Thins
* 3 tbsp unsalted butter, melted
* 1/2 cup freeze-dried strawberries
Filling
* 16oz vegan cream cheese, room temp
* 1 cup freeze-dried strawberries
* 2/3 cup sugar
* 1/2 cup coconut oil
* juice of 1 lemon (4 tbsp)
Process
1. To make the crust, blend together the sweet thins until fine. Add the melted butter and miso and blend until a sandy texture. Press into a 8” springform pan. Chill in fridge.
2. To make crumble: pulse together the freeze dried 🍓 and sweet thins until crumbly. add melted butter and pulse until combined. set aside
3. To make 🍓 strawberry cheese filling: blend freeze dried strawberries and 1/3c sugar until combined. Pour into a large bowl with 8oz cream cheese, and 1/4c coconut oil. Use a handheld mixer to while until light and fluffy. Add juice or 1/2 lemon and whip until incorporated. Set aside
4. To make regular filling: Using a handheld mixer, whip together remaining sugar, cream cheese, and coconut oil until combined. Add lemon juice and whip once more. 
5. Pour 🍓 filling into crust and smooth out. Pour plain filling on top and smooth out once more. Press the crumble on top and cover with plastic wrap. Refrigerate overnight
6. Slice with a wet knife, serve w/ macerated strawberries. 

#simplemillspartner #strawberrycheesecake #nobakedessert #summerdessert #cheesecake

C’mon Barbie! we’re making cold beet noodle soup 👛💄🎟️

This is a VERY far and adjacent version of Chlodnik or Borscht— but intentional with its use of root veggies that ground you and nourish you with every bite. 

idk, i think ken would make this for barbie if he knew how to use a can opener tbh.

here’s how to make it:
* 1lb beets
* 1/2 lb purple potatoes
* 1/2 yellow onion, diced
* 3 garlic cloves, minced
* 3 tbsp olive oil
* 1 tbsp miso
* 1/2 tsp cardamom
* 1 (15oz) can of coconut milk
* 2 cups water
* zest and juice of 2 lemons
* salt/pepper to taste
Process:
1. peel beets and potatoes then dice. Dice onion and mince garlic.
2. Heat olive oil over medium heat, add onions and garlic with a pinch of kosher salt and saute until translucent, about 4 to 5 minutes. Add the cardamom and miso and saute for a minute.
3. Pour in coconut milk and whisk until miso has dissolved. Pour in water and bring to a boil. Add the beets and potatoes and cook until fork tender, about 20 mins. Remove from heat
4. Once cool, blend it using an immersion blender or food processor. Add the lemon juice/zest and season with more salt/pepper.
5. Chill and serve with buckwheat noodles, fresh sweet corn, scallions, sauteed mushrooms, and a fried egg.
6. A squeeze of lemon and sesame seeds is non-negotiable. THEY! ARE! OUR! ACCESSORIES!

#beets #noodles #coldsoup

day 7 of making trifle the summer pastry “it” girl🤾🍑🎂 (recipe below) 

a no bake summer dessert is non negotiable when the sun is touching brains with you 🤾🌞 and even more perfect w/ @pureleaf’s Subtly Sweet Peach Tea #PureLeafPartner

is baking intimidating? sure, but is it when 70% of the ingredients can be store bought? never!

here’s how to make it:
Peach Syrup
-1 bottle Pure Leaf Subtly Sweet Peach Tea
-1/2 cup sugar
Tahini Cream Pudding
* 2c non-dairy milk of choice (I used oat milk)
* 1/4c cornstarch, sifted
* 1/2 tsp salt
* 1 tbsp vanilla extract
* 2/3 cup tahini
* 2 tbsp unsalted butter
* 1/2c confectioner’s sugar
Assembly
* (1) 9x9 sponge cake (1” cubes, about 4 cups)
* 1lb cherries
* 2lb peaches, sliced and grilled 
* 2 cups Non-dairy whip cream or cool whip

Process:
1. Make peach syrup by combining peach tea with sugar in a pot. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer. Cook for 5 mins. Let cool. 
2. Depit cherries and coat with 1/4 cup of peach syrup.
3. Make pudding: In a  bowl, whisk together milk, cornstarch, sugar, salt, & vanilla extract until combined. Stir in tahini. Pour into a saucepan and heat over medium heat. Cook for 5 mins while stirring.
4. Add the 2tbsp butter and continue stirring until the pudding begins to thicken. Pour into a glass bowl and cover with plastic wrap. Refrigerate for 2 hours till cool.
5. To assemble: Grill peaches. Cube sponge cake and toss with 1 cup of peach syrup (1/2c at a time). In a large glass bowl, layer a 1/2 of the pudding. Add 1/2 sponge cake, then peaches, cherries, whip cream and repeat.
6. Garnish with more whip cream, fresh peaches, and cherries 

#summerdessert #trifle #peaches #cherries

Zaalouk is the most delicious dip to ever grace this planet and it’s even better with pasta, period (RECIPE BELOW) 🍅🍆🇲🇦

This spread has been my favorite way to feel connected to my Moroccan heritage and seeing how many people enjoy it every time I make it just reminds me of my father and his compassion— giving to others when he had little for himself.

This is something that is nonnegotiable to make during the summer, with perfectly ripe eggplant and tomatoes. Here’s how to make it and turn it into a pasta sauce!

Process:
1 medium eggplant, cubed
2 pints grape tomatoes (I like sun gold and cherry)
4 garlic cloves, smashed
1/4 cup chopped parsley
1/4 cup chopped cilantro
1/4 cup olive oil
1 teaspoon coriander
1/2 teaspoon cumin seed
1/2 teaspoon sannam chili or chili powder
1 teaspoon salt (to start, add more to taste)
1/4 cup water
1 tablespoon tomato paste
Juice of 1 lemon
8oz bucatini pasta

1. In a pot, heat olive oil over medium low heat. Add the minced garlic and sauté until fragrant. Add the cumin, coriander, and chili and saute until fragrant. 
2. Add the eggplant, tomatoes, and water with 1 teaspoon of kosher salt. Toss to coat and cover to cook for 15-20 mins, stirring every 5 mins, until tomatoes and eggplant have softened and begin to melt together. 
3. Stir in tomato paste and lemon juice until combined. Cook for another 5-10 mins until the spread resembles a dip. Add the chopped parsley and cilantro last, cook for 2-3 more mins and remove from heat. Season with more salt if needed.
4. Serve as a dip, on a sandwich, or with pasta! To serve with pasta, add cooked bucatini or pasta of choice to the spread in a pan with some pasta cooking liquid (add 1/4 at a time until the sauce emulsifies and begins to coat the pasta)
5. Serve w/ parmigiano reggiano and fresh parsley.

#moroccanfood #tomatoseason #pastarecipes #eggplant

TEMBLEQUE— equally fun to make as it is to eat 🫨 🤲🏼🇵🇷 (RECIPE BELOW) 

Tembleque is a staple in Puerto Rico (and throughout the diaspora) during the summer- with each pudding shaking as much as the gorls do at Papi Juice

My brother and I begged my mom to stop the car so we could get tembleque from the street vendor growing up and it’s the few things that made me feel so connected to my heritage 

This pudding has a coconut milk base that welcomes new flavors with open arms, like the earthy grounding ones of clove and cardamom

Here’s how to make my version of my fav PR treat:
-2 (15oz) cans FULL FAT coconut milk
-3/4c sugar
-1/4 tsp salt
-6 tbsp cornstarch
-4 cardamom pods
-4 cloves
-1/4 tsp cinnamon
-1/2 tsp vanilla or almond extract
1. In a medium pot, combine the coconut milk and sugar. Reserve 1/2 cup of liquid in a bowl and whisk in the cornstarch until combined and smooth. Set aside.
2. Heat the coconut milk in the pot over medium heat and add the vanilla, cardamom pods, clove, cinnamon, and salt. Bring to a simmer and stir frequently for 10 mins.
3. Remove the cardamom/clove and whisk in the cornstarch mixture. Whisk over medium-low heat until it thickens (about 5-7 mins) The mixture should be runny enough to drizzle over something but thick enough to heavily coat the back of a spoon.
4. Pour into molds or into a glass and chill overnight.
5. Garnish with cinnamon and dive in!

#tembleque #coconutdessert #puertoricanfood

It’s 2023, enough of the eggplant slander- grow up! 🍆🫨🤾
This is my favorite way to have it (recipe below)

Fairytale eggplant is a little less daunting (size matters) if you’re trying to step away from the sad life that is eggplant slander. Salt, sear, and toss in a sweet and savory glaze is the three step, no frills way to take eggplant to the next level. 🤲🏼😌

Here’s how:
1 pint fairytale eggplant
1 (15-ounce) can of cannellini beans
1 scotch bonnet pepper, sliced
2 garlic cloves, minced
2 tbsp olive oil
1/4 cup chopped cilantro
(Honey Soy Glaze)
1 tbsp soy sauce
2 tbsp honey
1/2 tsp cumin
1/2 tsp coriander
1/4 smoked paprika
salt/pepper
(Mint Lime Labneh)
2/3 cup labneh or cashew yogurt
juice of 1 lime
2 tbsp chopped mint 
salt/pepper, to taste
Process:

1. Slice the fairytale eggplant in half. Place it on a plate and sprinkle with kosher salt. Let it sit for 10 minutes. Pat dry.
2. In a bowl, whisk together the ingredients for the glaze. Set aside.
3. Mince the garlic, slice the scotch bonnet pepper, and chop the cilantro. 
4. Heat the olive oil in a cast iron over medium heat. Add the dried eggplant face down and sear for 3-4 mins per side until golden. Remove and set aside.
5. In the same skillet, add 2 more tbsp olive oil. Sauté garlic and scotch bonnet peppers until fragrant. Add the glaze, drained beans and eggplant. Toss to coat and reduce to a simmer. 
6. Cook for 5-6 mins until the glaze thickens slightly. Add lime juice and fresh cilantro and toss to coat once more.
7. Make the mint labneh by mixing all of the ingredients together. 
8. Serve eggplant and beans over labneh with crusty bread. Garnish with mint and pistachios. 

#eggplant #beans #vegetarianrecipe

🥑🥛 Avocado milk- if you feel like you’re touching brains with the sun, make this (RECIPE BELOW ⬇️ )

This thique, smooth, lawlessly delicious drink is the epitome of my childhood. No weekend morning was complete without this and the most effervescent sprinkle of cinnamon on top. 

My Moroccon grandmother whipped this together in my moms decade’s old blender for us as a way to make sure we were well fed before going to any sports game in the dead heat of summer- and now it’s my favorite to share with loved one’s at BBQ’s and picnics alike :}

Here’s how to make it:
1 avocado
3 cups almond, soy, or cashew milk (I prefer a thinner non-dairy milk for this)
3-4 tbsp sweetener (sugar, honey, maple syrup, monk fruit, coconut sugar)
10-12 mint leaves
Pinch of sea salt
Pinch of cinnamon
1/2 tsp orange blossom water or almond extract

Process:
1. Remove the pit and skin from the avocado and blend with all of the ingredients in a high-speed blender until combined.
2. Taste and add more sugar or mint if needed. Blend in a couple ice cubes to serve immediately. 
3. Serve in a glass rimmed with sumac sugar 

#avocados #drinksofinstagram #moroccanfood

Delusion is the key to happiness! I’m so excited to be partnering with my favs, @dunkin , so y’all can get into delulu bev of choice to keep things silly 🫐☕️🧡🦩
 
I am a firm believer in you are what you drink, and NOTHING is more bold and smooth than @dunkin’s new Cold Brew Concentrate at-home #DunkinAtHome 
 
The power that a cold brew with blueberry syrup has is unmatched, and you can easily make it by making Blueberry Cheong, a traditional Korean culinary technique that uses sugar to preserve and extract the juices from fruit (typically yuzu or lemons but it works great with 🫐🫐🫐)
 
Here’s how to make Frozen Cold Brew with Blueberry Cheong
 
1 cup Dunkin’ Cold Brew Concentrate
1 cup water
180 grams blueberries (I prefer using frozen)
180 grams granulated sugar
Coconut condensed milk
Milk of choice
Flakey Salt
 
Process:
 
Make the blueberry cheong: If using fresh blueberries, rinse well and pat dry. In a STERILIZED AND CLEAN jar, add equal parts of blueberries and sugar. Close, shake and place into a cool, dark place for 1 week, shaking once a day. Once the blueberries begin to shrivel up and the sugar dissolves, drain the liquid from the blueberries and use for our cold brew.
 
To make the cold brew: Combine the Cold Brew Concentrate with water. Place into a container or ice cube tray and freeze overnight. Once frozen, add to a food processor and pulse until coarse (about 4 to 5 pulses). Pour into a bowl and freeze until ready to serve.
 
Drizzle condensed milk around the glass. Add whole blueberries from the cheong on the bottom, top w/ the frozen cold brew, and garnish w/ a splash of oatmilk and the blueberry syrup. 
 
Sprinkle flakey salt on top then stir and sip. DIVE IN!

Gochujang Sesame Chickpea Salad is my favorite way to use up that dusty can of beans in your pantry (and it’s better than that dry wrap from Trader Joe’s (recipe below)

I ate the same turkey hummus sandwich everyday throughout college because it felt the most financially responsible during a time when I paid my way through school and living in NYC away from my parents. Making more flavorful and fulfilling options now makes me sad for that version of myself who honestly didn’t know better. But I hope I can live vicariously through you now ♥️

1 tbsp gochujang (Korean-fermented red pepper paste)
1 tbsp yogurt (or mayo…)
1 tbsp tahini
Juice of 1 lime
1 tbsp chopped cilantro, optional but recommended
1/2 tsp coriander
1/2 tsp cumin
dash of cinnamon
1 (15oz) can of cannellini/chickpea beans or 1-2 cans of tuna
salt/pepper to taste
Process:
1. Drain the beans/tuna and mash. Add the gochujang, yogurt, tahini, and lime juice. Mix until combined. Add the spices, herbs, and salt/pepper to taste. Refrigerate until ready to assemble
2. Toast sourdough in a skillet and rub 1 garlic clove over the toasted bread. Spread goat cheese on one side, and layer on sauteed zucchini/squash. Add greens of choice on top, and your bean salad.
3. Slice in half, serve w/ potato chips, and dive in 🏊🏽‍♂️

#chickpeasalad #beans #easylunch #sandwichlover

🌽 Miso-Moroccan Spiced Corn Soup is your LAST CHANCE to try cold soup before the fall sksksk girlies take over (RECIPE BELOW)

I was hesitant about cold soup at first too, but this journey has altered my brain chemistry. I’m so sad to see it go but happy to see hot soups in forseeable future

But for the time being DROP THE FALL DECOR, SIT DOWN AND MAKE THIS — we have 3 weeks left 

4 tbsp salted butter
1/2 yellow onion, diced
1 1/2 tbsp ras el hanout
4 ears corn
2 tbsp white miso
3 cups water
1 (15oz) can full fat coconut milk
1 (15oz) can white beans (optional)
zest and juice of 1 lime
salt/pepper to taste

{gochujang marinated tomatoes}
1/2 cup sliced grape tomatoes
1 tbsp gochujang 
juice of 1/2 lime
1 tbsp chopped cilantro
salt/pepper to taste

process:

1/ Remove corn from the cob and cut the cobs in half. Set aside. In a pot over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the onions and sauté until softened, about 5-6 mins. Add the ras el hanout and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant

2/ Add the 3 cups water and whisk in the miso paste until dissolved. Add the corn kernels/cobs and submerge them. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook for 20 mins, covered.

3/ Remove corn cobs from the pot and add the can of coconut milk and cook for an additional 2-3 mins. Using an immersion blender, blend until smooth. If using a regular blender, let cool before blitzing.

4/ Stir in the lime juice and lime zest and season with salt/pepper to taste. Let chill before serving. 

5/ Marinate the tomatoes with the gochujang, lime juice, cilantro, salt and pepper.

6/ Garnish soup with marinated tomatoes, olive oil, and aleppo pepper

#coldsoup #corn #veganrecipe #souprecipes

if you DESPISE eggplant, “Moutabbal” is the best way to prepare it (recipe below ⬇️)

This is a dupe from @elephante’s famous “eggplant dip” which is essentially Moutabbal- a middle eastern dip similar to baba ghanoush with the main difference being the addition of tahini 

its creamy, slightly sweet, and nutty— making it the perfect dish for any spread or sandwich tbqh

✨Here’s how you can make liquid gold✨
* 1 eggplant
* 1/4 cup (vegan) cream cheese
* 2 tbsp tahini
* 2 tbsp olive oil
* 2 garlic clove
* 1 tbsp maple syrup
* Salt/pepper, to toaste
Directions:
1. Slice eggplant in half and pierce the skin and flesh with a fork. Drizzle with 2 to 3 tbsp of olive oil. Roast for 30 to 40 minutes in a preheated 400 degree oven.
2. Let cool. Remove the skin, remove the seeds (for smoother texture) and add to a processor with cream cheese, tahini, olive oil, garlic, maple syrup, and salt/pepper(about 1/2 tsp or more to taste)
3. Blend for 4 to 5 minutes or until smooth and silky. Taste and adjust the seasoning per your preference.
4. Garnish with a drizzle of EVOO, shallot & garlic crisp, and Aleppo pepper (or red pepper flakes)
5. Dive in!

#eggplant #easyveganrecipes #middleeasternfood

Elote Salad 🤝 Sweetgreen Dupe 🤝 your Savings 💰🫰 (recipe below) 

I’ve never met a salad that was worth prepping for 2 hours than this one. And yes it does take 2 hours, but so does debating on whether you should send that risky text. Pick your battle 

Here’s how to make it

{Charred Corn}
* 1 cup corn kernels
* 1 bell pepper, diced
* 2 tbsp olive oil
{Cilantro Lime (No) Mayo Dressing}
* 2 garlic cloves
* 1/2 cup cilantro
* 4 tbsp olive oil
* 2 tbsp acv
* Zest of 1 lime
* Juice of 1 lime
* 1/2 tsp cumin
* 2 tbsp nutritional yeast
* salt/pepper to taste
Salad Mix-In’s
*  12-ounces of arugula
* 1 cup shredded red cabbage
 * seasoned with juice of 1 lemon, salt/pepper
* 1 cup wild rice/quinoa/barley/faro
* 1 cup chopped grape tomatoes
* 1/2 cup slivered spicy almonds, for garnish
* cotija cheese, for garnish (substitute with any vegan or non-vegan farmers cheese)
* tajin, for garnish (substitute with any vegan or non-vegan farmers cheese)
Process
1. Heat skillet with olive oil over med heat. Char corn and peppers for about 5 mins. Season with salt/pepper Set aside.
2. In a food processor, blend all dressing ingredients until combined. If too thick, add 1 tbsp water at a time to thin. Taste and adjust seasoning.
3. Toss arugula with 2 tbsp of dressing. Garnish with cabbage, tomatoes, and charred corn. quinoa, cotija cjeese, spicy almonds, and tajin

#elote #easysalads #veganlunchideas

Iced Mai Thai Tea Cocktail for when you’re mentally ready for fall but still touching brains with the sun and the air conditioner 😵‍💫

Crafted this cocktail for @marcjacobs last year and it was a hit which just means it’ll be for you too 😋❤️

Thai Ice Tea is truly a delicacy and it’s so easy to make at home with your favorite black tea and a handful of spices! Here’s how:

(Thai Tea)
2 whole star anise 
2 pods green cardamom, crushed
1 pc cinnamon stick 
2 teaspoon turmeric
1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
2 bottles of Pure Leaf Subtly Sweet Tea
3 to 4 drops red food coloring (for color, optional)
(Cocktail)
4oz Thai tea
1 oz white rum
1 oz amaretto liquer
1/2 oz orgeat
1/2 oz lime juice
Pinch of salt
Frothed Oat Milk, to garnish
Sliced Lime, to garnish
Mint leaves, to garnish
Sumac Sugar, to garnish (1 tbsp sumac + 1 tbsp white sugar)

Process: 1. To make the tea, combine the Pure Leaf tea with the spices and vanilla extract. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer for 10 minutes. Strain and chill. 
2. To make the cocktail, prepare your glasses by slicing a 1/4 of a lime wedge and removing it to run the rim of the glass in. Once a portion of the glass is wet with lime juice, run it through the sumac-sugar and place in the freezer to chill. 
3. Add ice to a cocktail shaker. Pour in the tea, rum, amaretto, orgreat, lime juice, and salt. Shake until frothy. Pour into your chilled glass and add about 2 tbsp of frothed oat milk on top. Garnish with lime and mint.

#thaiicedtea #cocktailsathome #fundrinks

If there’s one thing I beg of you to make, it’s Zaalouk. It’s simply perfect 🇲🇦🍅🍆 

This moroccan tomato eggplant dip is zesty, bright, full of depth, flavor, and beauty like you (cause you are whag you eat 🤭) It was my first dish I learned to make from my dad and the one I make to feel most connected to my Moroccan heritage ♥️ 

Plus it’s so similar to so many other dishes around the world like Indian Baingan bharta or Romanian Zacusca proving that we’re all more similar and closer to one another than we think (including your next boo when you make this for them)

Here’s how to make it:
* 1 eggplant, peeled and cubed 
* 3 Roma tomatoes, peeled, deseeded, and cored 
* 4 garlic cloves, smashed 
* 1/3 cup chopped parsley
* 1/4 cup olive oil
* 1 tsp coriander
* 1 tsp cumin
* 1/2 tsp cayenne
* 1 tsp sea salt, add more to taste
* 1/4 cup water, more to thin
* 1 tbsp tomato paste 
* juice of 1 lemon
1. In a pot, add the eggplant, tomatoes, garlic, parsley, oil, spices, and water. Bring to a simmer and cook, covered, for 10-25 minutes. Stir continuously, allowing the eggplant and tomatoes to mesh together into a dip consistency.
2. Once softened, use a wooden spoon to mash the contents of the pan into a dip consistency.
3. Add tomato paste and lemon juice. Stir and season with salt and pepper. 
4. Simmer, uncovered, for another 10 minutes. The dip is ready to be served when it can coat the wooden spoon.
5. Plate. Drizzle olive oil and garnish with olives, lemon wedges, and chopped parsley.
6. Dive in!

#moroccanfood #zaalouk #easyappetizers

Brazilian Carrot Cake is just the superior, more efficient way to make the highly slandered (ICONIC) cake— and it’s the perfect birthday cake for MmeeeEeeeEeeee

It’s so incredibly moist thanks to coconut oil and it has the most gorgeous orange hue ♥️ It’s not traditionally made with cinnamon and nutmeg and clove but we could always use a little warmth and the world is on fire so do what brings you joy 

Here’s how to make it: 
- 200g peeled carrots, cut into chunks (about 3-4 carrots)
- 2 eggs (sub with flax eggs)
- 3/4 cup + 2 tbsp white sugar
- 2/3 cup Raw Extra Virgin coconut oil, melted
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 1 cup, 3 tbsp all-purpose flour
- 2 tbsp cornstarch
- 2 tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp cinnamon
-1/2 tsp ginger
- 1/2 tsp nutmeg
- 1/2 tsp salt
-1/4 cup chopped pistachios,
-1/4 of raisins soaked in 1 cup of amaretto liqu0r, wine, or apple juice
- Coconut Cream Cheese Frosting (recipe in comments)
Directions:
1. If using raisins, soak them in your liquid of choice for 2 to 3 hours, preferably overnight.
2. Preheat oven to 350F. Make flax eggs. Grease an 8” bundt pan. Set aside.
3. In a bowl, whisk together dry ingredients. Set aside.
4. In a food processor, combine carrots, flax eggs, sugar, coconut extract & coconut oil until smooth. You can leave some carrot shreds if you want some extra texture.
5. Fold wet mixture into the dry until incorporated with no flour remaining. Fold in your mix-ins.
6. Pour batter into cake pan. Bake for 35 to 40 minutes (on the CENTER RACK) until a clean toothpick comes out when inserted in the middle.
7. Let the cake cool for 10 minutes in the pan & transfer to a wire rack for another 1 to 2 hours. 
8. Garnish the cake with the coconut cream cheese frosting, coconut flakes & chopped pistachios

#carrotcake #cakerecipes #braziliandessert

Wilting Greens turned into pesto for tteokbokki is my favorite personality (and way to help lessen food waste) — 😤🫰🌱

I was so determined to try tteokbokki with pesto since I came across a video of it being served in Korea 

and simple sauce is one of my favorite ways to use up any condiments, herbs, or greens in my fridge so they don’t go to waste while i’m gone during a trip. 🫰 P.S. a little layer of olive oil once it’s placed in a jar will help preserve that sauce in the fridge too for a couple weeks.

Here’s how to make it:
4pz spinach leaves
1oz basil leaves
3/4 cup coconut milk
2 tbsp nutritional yeast
1 tbsp za’atar
juice of 1/2 lemon
salt/pepper to tasste

Process: 
1. To a blender, blitz together the greens, basil, coconut milk, nutritional yeast, za’atar, lemon juice, salt/pepper until smooth. Taste and adjust seasoning.
2. Prepare your frozen tteokbokki bh boiling or steaming them. Drain and pat them dry. Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a skillet and sauté until slightly crispy. Add the  pesto and bring to a simmer.
3. Blister your sun gold tomatoes in 2 tbsp olive oil with salt/pepper, cover and cook for 10 mins. 

#tteokbokki #foodwaste #easydinnerrecipes

Rice bowls for feral girl fall- specifically this harissa sardine one that uses mostly pantry staples. (recipe below) 

A lot of people indulge in slander of the “condiment” fridge— but it’s one of the most versatile. Flavor bombs that last for months in the back of your fridge make it that much easier throw something together and feel like the bad ass binch you are

here’s how to make the harissa sardine bowl:
1 yellow onion, diced
2 garlic cloves, minced
3 tbsp butter
3 tbsp harissa
2 tsp vegetable base
1 cup water (sub w/ stock if you don’t have vegetable base)
1 pint grape tomatoes
1-2 tins sardines
2 tbsp chopped parsley
Rice, to serve
Parsley, to serve
Egyptian dukkah or chopped pistachios

Process:
1. In a skillet, saute onion and garlic over medium heat in the melted butter. Add the harissa and sauté until sticky and slightly reduced.
2. Add the vegetable base and water (or vegetable stock) and bring to a simmer. Add the grape tomatoes, toss to coat. Cook, covered, for 10 mins.
3. While tomatoes cook, make your rice, chop your parsley, and drain your sardines. 
4. Add the sardines and parsley to the tomatoes and let simmer for an additional 5 mins. 
5. Season to taste with salt/pepper. Serve over rice with a lemon wedge, Egyptian dukkah or chopped pistachios, and fresh parsley

#sardines #ricebowl #easydinnerideas #harissa

my new personality is Bún Cha😭🫰 my Hanoi, Vietnam guide is below! 

Hanoi is one of the most exuberant cities I’ve ever visited. It’s full of the most delectable treats, incredible craftspeople, and heart racing motorbike rides. Beep Beep- here’s where you should eat, visit, drink! 🏍️🏍️

Coffee/Drinks: Always get Coconut Coffee (Cafe Cot Dua)
- The LOBI Coffee in long biên: Beautiful, modern interiors with delicious coconut coffee 🥥
- @bonjourcafevn in Quang An: Hibiscus Coffee… that is all 🌺🌺🌺
*Get sugarcane juice (Nuoc Mia) from any vendor. You’ll spot the machine they use to press all that perfect juicyness from the stalks 

Food
- @banhbaobinhmo (in Hang Bong): the best banh mi i’ve ever put in my mouth in hanoi… juicy, flavorful, colorful! 
- Banh Cam (Sesame Donut Balls): you can find these from vendors throughout the city center in hanoi!! they are delectable, savory and sweet with the perfect chew 
- Che: if you thought beans couldn’t be sweet, CHE IS THE MF ANSWER. This textural goddess is the perfect dessert thats not to sweet but full of flavors from coconut milk, tapioca pearls, and sweetened red beans
- Bun Cha: the two best in Hanoi can be found at Bun Cha-Nem Cua Be (in Hang Bac, Hanoi) and Bun Cha 41 Cue (in Cua Dong, Hanoi)

Shopping:
- Super Nasty Vintage @supernastyvintage
- Vintage Stadium @vintage.stadium 
*My main tip is to just WALK! Walk everywhere, use google translate to communicate with vendors. Some streets are dedicated to specific kinds of goods. Metal street, clothing street, bamboo street! ALL THE STREETS!
*Take a boxing class!! Between the humidity and the stamina that vietnamese trainers have, you will be dropping out every ounce of coconut coffee you had before 😤

#hanoifood #vietnamtravel #bahnmi

Creamy, Nutty Korma-ish meatballs 🤝 rice 🤝 pomegranate seeds— a 45-minute (plant-based) meal that could last you a week if you ~somehow~ avoid getting seconds or thirds

Climate week started yesterday and was a good reminder for me to implement more ways to use plant-based swaps every day, when possible of course. Plant-based meat has consistently gotten more slander than a Gemini in heat— but the key is to ensure it’s seasoned well and doused in something that takes the “more is more” approach.

This korma-inspired sauce is the perfect way to hide the fact that your dinner is actually made from plants and is delicious at it! Here’s how to make it:

Meatballs
- 1lb vegan meat
- 1/2 red onion, minced
- 2 tbsp cilantro
- 1 tsp cumin
- 1 tsp cayenne
- 2 tbsp olive oil
Sauce:
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1 shallot, minced
- 3 garlic cloves, minced
- 2 inches ginger, grated
- 1 tsp each cumin, coriander, turmeric
- 1/2 tbsp garam masala
- 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper
- 1 (15oz) can full-fat coconut milk
- 2 tablespoons cashew or sunflower seed butter
- 1/2 cup water
- 2 tbsp chopped cilantro
- 1 teaspoon salt or to taste
- fresh cilantro and lime for topping

1.Season your plant-based meat with red onion, cilantro, cumin, and cayenne pepper. Drizzle olive oil on your hands, take 1 1/2 tbsp of the seasoned plant-based meat, and roll into balls. Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a skillet over medium heat and sear the balls until slightly charred on all sides, about 3-4 mins per side

2.Remove the meat and add 2 more tbsp olive oil. Saute the shallot, garlic, and ginger until softened, about 2-3 minutes. Add the spices to the aromatics and saute until fragrant, about 2 minutes.

3.Whisk in the coconut milk and nut butter until combined. Add the water and a pinch of salt to season. Bring to a simmer and add the meatballs into the sauce. Sprinkle the cilantro over the meatballs, cover, and cook for 5 to 10 minutes. 

4.Serve over rice with fresh cilantro, pomegranate seeds, chopped cashews and a lime wedge. 

5.Dive iinnNNnnnnn

#korma #ricebowls #plantbaseddinner

Smoky Carrot Dip because carrots deserve the same respect that the pumps and squash get 😤🥕

i love blending a veggie with beans, spices, herbs, and a little douse of acidity for the perfect opportunity to see the flavors that pair well for you & that veggie!

when I tell you @simplemills Rosemary Sea Salt Almond Flour crackers are so delicious, it inspired my now boyfriend to slide into my DMs to say the same thing 😭— they’re made with an almond, sunflower, and flax seed flour blend so you can feel GOOD about these snacking moments #simplemillspartner 

- 6 large carrots, chopped into 2” pieces
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1 tsp cinnamon
- 1/2 tsp nutmeg
- 1/2 tsp smoked paprika
- big pinch of sea salt
- 2/3 cup hazelnuts, roasted
- 1 (15oz) can of white beans,
- 3 tablespoons orange juice
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1/2 to 1 teaspoon sea salt, to taste
- 1/2 tsp cinnamon
- 1/4 tsp nutmeg
- crispy sage leaves, to garnish
- chopped hazelnuts, to garnish
- sprinkle chili/cayenne, to garnish

1. Toss carrots with 3 tbsp olive oil, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, and a generous pinch of sea salt. Roast for 25 to 30 mins in a preheated 375F oven until the carrots or fork tender
3. During the last 5 mins of roast time, add hazelnuts to another tray and roast. This will help them release their oils and become more fragrant. Remove from the oven and let cool. For a more restaurant-quality texture, you will want to remove the skins of the hazelnuts by adding hazelnuts to a jar and shake it until the nuts are bare.
4. Blend the hazelnuts in a food processor until fine. Add the carrots, drained white beans, orange juice, olive oil, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, and a pinch of salt to a food processor.
5. Blend until smooth (about 3 to 4 minutes). If the mixture needs more liquid, add 1-2 tbsp of cold water until desired consistency. Taste the mixture and adjust the seasoning (salt, cinnamon, nutmeg) based on personal preference.
6. Once smooth, pour into a dish. Drizzle with EVOO and add crispy sage leaves.

#carrotrecipes #easyappetizers #carrots #hazelnuts

😤🫰 Gochujang-Tahini Cauliflower steaks but make it a whole ass meal (RECIPE BELOW ⬇️) 

I’ve seen a many cauliflower steaks as a main dish on menus… with a side of greens and cannot fathom doing my digestive system dirty like that— and neight should you girl!
This is my favorite way to add some extra depth and protein with flavor to the gassy veggie

1 head cauliflower
2 tbsp gochujang
2 tbsp tahini
2 tbsp maple syrup
1 tbsp rice vinegar
1/2 tbsp sesame oil
1/2 tsp cumin
salt/pepper to taste
(Bean Puree)
1 can cannelinni beans
2 tbsp tahini
3-4 tbsp lemon juice
1/4 tsp nutmeg
water, to thin
parmigiano regginao, to garnish
chopped tarragon, to garnish
pistachios, to garnish
{Process}
1. Preheat oven to 400F. Slice cauliflower horizontally into 2” steaks. Place onto a baking tray with parchment paper that has a drizzle of oil on it.
2. Mix together gochujang, tahini, maple syrup, vinegar, sesame oil, cumin and season w/ salt. Using a pastry brush, brush the sauce on both sides of the cauliflower. Reserve 1-2 tbsp for garnish.
3. Roast the cauliflower for 25-30 mins in the middle rack, flipping the cauliflower midway through.
4. While they bake, puree a can of beans with tahini, lemon juice, nutmeg, salt/pepper until smooth with no lumps. Add 1 tbsp cold water at a time to thin, if needed.
5. Once baked, spread bean puree over a plate. Place cauliflower on top and garnish w/ grated parmigiano reggiano, chopped tarragon, and pistachios

#cauliflowersteak #gochujang #easyveganrecipes #dinnerideas

‼️(Anti-Pumpkin) Sweet Potato Moroccan Spiced Chocolate Cookies— a mouthful for a mouthful 😽🫶 (RECIPE BELOW)

Compassion is key! Give pumpkin the same rest you give yourself— rest of productive 🫰 These are sweet and savory thanks to Ras El Hanout (a moroccan blend of 14 spices that feel better than that weighted blanket you sleep with to comfort you) and so so decadent 

Here’s how to make it
* 1 ¼ cup all-purpose flour
* 1 tbsp cornstarch
* 1 1/2 tsp ras el hanout
 * sub with 1/2 tsp each of cinnamon & ginger, and 1/4 tsp each of clove, allspice, nutmeg
* 1/2 tsp baking powder
* 1/2 tsp baking soda
* 8 tbsp coconut oil, room temp
* 1/2 cup + 2 tbsp dark brown sugar, PACKED
* 1/4 cup white sugar
* 1/4 cup sweet potato puree
* 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
* 3 tbsp white miso paste
* 1 cup dark chocolate chunks
* 1/2 cup chocolate chips
Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Bring all ingredients to room temp
2. In a bowl, whisk together the flour, cornstarch, ras el hanout, baking powder, & baking soda. Set aside.
3. Cream together the coconut oil and brown/white sugar for 2 to 3 minutes until light and fluffy. Add the sweet potato puree, vanilla extract, and white miso paste. Cream together until combined.
4. Fold dry ingredients to the wet and mix until a cookie dough consistency comes together. Add the chocolate and fold until combined
5. Chill the cookie dough overnight, preferably. If you’re in a pinch, you can choose to freeze the dough for 1 hour or until hardened.
6. Place the dough evenly on a parchment-lined tray, 2 inches apart. Bake in the middle rack of the oven for 10-12 mins. Remove and bang tray on counter to help spread cookies out with a ripple effect. Let cookies cool on tray.

#fallbaking #raselhanout #sweetpotatoes #cookierecipe

Harissa Mushroom Cous Cos soup is the IT girl that should honestly have butternut squash soup shaking in her boots (recipe below)

Like… I love butternut squash soup as much as the next UGG-TJ MAXX girly, but she’s ran through. Yes, panera bread’s autumn squash soup is a serve and a half— minus the inflation— but this mushroom cous cous soup is better :’) 

It’s the nepo baby of minestrone and butternut squash soup— with kabocha, harissa, cous cos, and a runny egg because it’s more silly that way

Here’s how to make it:
1 medium yellow onion, diced
3 garlic cloves, minced
2 cups chopped kabocha squash, skin on
1 pint shiitake mushrooms, quartered 
1 teaspoon cumin
1 tablespoon veggie stock base
2 tablespoons harissa paste
8 cups water
1 cup pearl cous cous
juice of 1/2 lemon (2 tablespoons)
fresh tarragon, chopped
1. Prepare the vegetables: Dice the yellow onion and mince garlic cloves. Rinse kabocha squash, remove seeds, and chop into 2-inch pieces. Clean your mushrooms and quarter them. 
2.  Heat olive oil in a pot over medium-low heat. Add the onion and garlic with a pinch of kosher salt. Saute until softened and onions are transparent. Add cumin, vegetable stock base, and harissa paste. Saute with the onions/garlic.
3. Stir in the water and bring to a simmer. Add the chopped kabocha squash, cover, and cook for 20-25 minutes. Stir and add cous cous. Cook for 6-8 mins until tender and add greens. Stir for 3-4 minutes.
4. Add lemon juice and season with/ salt and pepper if needed.
5. Serve w/ a runny egg, grated parmigiano reggiano.

Coffee Tres Leches minus the leches— for the dairy-intolerant girlies (recipe below) 
 
This is the most moist perfect dessert to have with the ICONIC @remyMartinus “Carajillo”: The only drink to kick espresso martinis to the gutter #ad21
 
Something about a little caffeine after a DELECTABLE dinner just feels right because my taurus moon wants to sleep but my Gemini rising wants to LIVE. This dairy-free take on the classic Latin Tres Leches cake is perfect to have post-dinner, pre-celebration, and maybe a little cure the next morning once the party is done 
 
Here’s how to make the cake and drink:
(The Rémy Martin Carajillo)
* 1 oz Rémy Martin 1738 Accord Royal
* 0.25 oz Cointreau
* 2 oz brewed espresso
Pour 1 oz Rémy Martin 1738 Accord Royal, 0.25 oz Cointreau, and 2 oz brewed espresso into a shaker filled with ice. Shake until chilled and pour in a rocks glass over ice. 
 
(Tres Leches Cake)
* 1 1/4 cup oat milk
* 2 tsp apple cider vinegar
* 2 cups flour
* 1 tsp baking soda
* 1/2 tsp baking powder
* 1/2 tsp kosher salt
* 1/3 cup vegetable oil
* 2/3 cup sugar
* 1 tbsp orange blossom water
* 1/2 tsp almond extract
* 12oz coconut condensed milk
* 8oz oat evaporated milk
* 4oz oat milk
* 2 tbsp espresso powder
-Preheat oven to 350F and grease a 8x8 pan. Whisk together the oat milk and vinegar in a bowl. Set aside. In a large bowl combine the flour, baking soda/powder, and salt. In the bowl with oat milk, whisk in the sugar, oil, orange blossom, and almond extract. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry and fold until combined. Pour into the cake pan and bake for 25-30 mins in the middle rack. Cool for 30. While cooling, combine espresso powder with the condensed, evaporated, and oat milk until combined. Poke the cake around 20-25 times with a fork or skewer and pour the milks on top. Cover and refrigerate overnight to soak. Add vegan whipped cream/cool whip on top before serving and garnish with chocolate shavings. QUE VIVA SOBREMESA
