🫰This cous cous salad is better than any other leafy green salad you shove in your mouth (recipe below) 

A grain bowl is just inherently more iconic than a salad- it’s more filling and the options are ENDLESS like your kind is. The versatility between grain choices, vegetables to add, and garnishes to stare at before you devour it just make it more exciting— provided by @wholefoods 

Here’s how to make it:
1 cup pearl cous cous
1 lb butternut squash, cubed
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp maple syrup
1/2 tsp five spice
1/4 tsp cayenne pepper
(Dressing)
2 tbsp tahini
1 tbsp maple syrup
1/2 tbsp sesame oil
juice of 1/2 lemon 
1/2 tsp five spice
1/4 tsp cayenne 
salt/pepper to taste
(Add Ins)
halved cucumbers, to garnish
2-3 tbsp chopped tarragon, to garnish
1 gala apple, cubed
1/4 cup pomegranate seeds, to garnish

1. Preheat oven to 375F. Peel squash, remove seeds, and cube into 1” pieces. Pour onto a parchment lined tray. Drizzle with olive oil, maple syrup, five spice, cayenne, and salt. Use your hands to evenly coat all the squash. Roast for 20-25 mins until tender.
2. Make dressing by combing the tahini, maple syrup, sesame oil, lemon juice, five spice, cayenne, salt/pepper. Whisk until combined. Set aside.
3. While squash roasts, make your pearl cous cous according to directions. Drain and set aside. Chop your cucumbers, tarragon, and apple. Toss the apple with a little lemon juice to prevent browning
4. Toss cous cous with the dressing until evenly coated. Add in about 1/2-1 cup of squash, cucumbers, tarragon, apple, and pomegranate seeds. Garnish w/ goat cheese, more tarragon.

#couscous #fallsalad #saladideas #butternutsquash

Teamed up with @wholefoods to bring you this Moroccan Spiced Chilean Sea Bass, Preserved Lemon Cream Sauce, and Pumpkin Talkari for when you want something more than pasta 
 
I was in charge of date night could only think of was this gorgie sea bass I saw at @wholefoods during their Spice Up Autumn sales event and had to pair it with my aunt’s Trinidadian Pumpkin Talkari
 
I love using food as a love language and get so excited to share recipes from childhood with ones I love, including you :’) 
 
(Fish)
1 lb Sustainable Wild-Caught Chilean Sea Bass fillets
1 tbsp olive oil
2 tbsp lemon juice
1/2 tsp salt
ras el hanout
 
(Cream Sauce)
1 tbsp butter
1/2 preserved lemon, minced
1 tbsp flour
3 tbsp white wine (must be 21+, drink and cook responsibly)
3 tbsp coconut cream
1/3 tbsp tarragon, chopped
1/4 tsp nutmeg, fresh
salt/pepper to taste
 
(Pumpkin Talkari)
* 2lb kabocha
* 1/4 cup olive oil
* 6 garlic cloves, minced
* 1/2 to 1 bunch of cilantro, finely chopped
* 1 medium yellow onion, diced
* 1 tsp red pepper flakes
* 1 tsp salt, to start
* 1 tbsp brown sugar
 
Process
1. To make pumpkin talkari: Peel kabocha squash and chop into 1/2” pieces. Mince garlic, onion, and chop cilantro. Heat olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Sauté the garlic, onion, red pepper flakes, and salt. Add pumpkin, toss to coat, then add 1/3 cup water. Cook for 10 mins, covered. Reduce heat to low and stir every couple of minutes, using back of a spoon to mash the pumpkin. Add water a tbsp at a time if needed. Once mashed, stir in the brown sugar, cilantro, and more salt if needed. Cover and keep warm.
2. To make sauce: Chop tarragon. Heat butter in a pan over medium heat. Add preserved lemon and flour; sauté for 2 mins. Add white wine and bring to a simmer for 3 mins. Stir in coconut cream. Add nutmeg and tarragon. Season with salt if needed. Set aside.
3. To make fish: Preheat oven to 400F. Cut fish into fillets. Pat dry. Mix together lemon juice, olive oil, and salt. Brush over both sides of the fish on a parchment-lined tray. Sprinkle ras el hanout on top. Bake for 15 mins. Serve fish on top of pumpkin. Garnish with cream sauce.

#kabochasquash #weeknightdinner #seafoodrecipes

🇲🇦 🫘 Loubia: Moroccan Stewy Tomato Beans— the perfect one pot meal (RECIPE BELOW ⬇️)

During times of hardship, when the world, your mind, your environment feels rough to sift through— I gravitate towards nourishing meals that take me away to ground myself so I can return back with a clearer mind and soul

This pot of beans isn’t going to bring peace, but may it bring ease and simplicity into your life when you need it most and the time to reflect on the current events around you

* 2 cans cannellini beans, drained
* (1) 15-ounce can of crushed tomatoes
* 1/2 medium yellow onion, diced
* 4 garlic cloves, minced
* 1/2 cup olive oil
* 3 tbsp fresh parsley, chopped
* 3 tbsp fresh cilantro, chopped
* 2 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
* 2 tbsp tomato paste
* 1/2 tablespoon cumin
* 1 teaspoons ginger
* 1 teaspoon cinnamon
* 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg
* 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper (optional)
* 2 cups water
* juice of 1/2 lemon
* chopped parsley, for garnish
* lemon zest, for garnish
* drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil, for garnish
1. In a large pot, heat olive oil over med heat. Add onions and garlic and sauté for 5 minutes. Saute the tomato paste and spices (ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, cumin, and cayenne pepper) for about 30 seconds.
2. Add the beans, tomato, water, chopped parsley/cilantro, and about 2 tsp salt
3. Bring the beans to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce to a simmer, cover, and let simmer for about 30 minutes. Taste the broth and adjust the seasoning by adding more salt (if needed), or any other spices like cinnamon, cumin, ginger, nutmeg, or cayenne per your personal preference.
5. For thicker stew let the stew simmer for about 20 minutes, uncovered, stirring consistently. Using a wooden spoon, lightly mash the beans for a creamier texture. Add lemon juice.
7. Plate and garnish with olive oil, chopped fresh parsley, lemon zest. Serve with crunchy bread.

#moroccanfood #beans #comfortfoodrecipes #stews

anything but the sink cookies is my FAVORITE way to use up those dusty bags of snacks in your cupboard (recipe below ⬇️)

the perfect cookie is crunchy on the bottom
and soft in the center— but the key is using flax eggs instead of a real one 🥚 made with @gardenoflife golden flax meal for some healthy omega’s (it’s also delicious in smoothies). #golpartner

here’s how to make it:
* 1 cup all-purpose flour
* 1/2 tsp baking powder
* 1/4 tsp baking soda
* 1 tsp cornstarch
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, softened
* 1/2 cup white sugar
* 1/3 cup light brown sugar, firmly packed 
* 1 flax egg (1 tbsp @gardenoflife golden flax meal + 3 tbsp water)
* 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
{Compost Mix}
* 1/2 cup crushed potato chips 
* 1/2 cup crushed pretzels
* 2 graham crackers, crushed
* 1/2 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips or chunks
* 2 tbsp rolled oats (not quick cook)
* 2 tsp coffee grounds (not instant coffee)
DIRECTIONS
1. Preheat oven to 350f
2. In a small bowl, combine all of the compost mix ingredients; set aside
3. In a separate larger bowl, cream together the softened butter and two sugars
4. Add flax egg and vanilla extract; beat until combined and set aside
5. In a medium bowl, sift the flour, baking powder, baking soda, cornstarch, and salt; whisk until combined
6. Fold the dry ingredients into the wet until JUST combined
7. Using wet hands, or a cookie scoop, form 2” cookie dough balls (of goodness); refrigerate for 1 hour (minimum) or overnight
8. Place chilled cookie dough on parchment lined trays and slightly press them down to create a slight disk shape
9. Bake for 14-16 mins, rotating trays midway through bake time
10. Let cool
11. Garnish with flakey sea salt
12. Dive in!

hummus, to assemble

Red Pepper-Rosemary Jelly is now my autumnal hyperfixation— for any party, sandwich, and savory oatmeal (recipe below)

Being obsessed with anything sweet and spicy is my new personality and red pepper jelly is the matriarch of this feen. It works beautifully layered over a vegan feta spread and on top of @simplemills Seed Flour Crackers that are nutrient-dense thanks to a 3-seed flour blend (of sunflower seeds, flax seeds, and pumpkin seeds) making them the perfect flakey base to top! #simplemillspartner
Here’s how to make it:
About 3 red bell peppers, cut into 1” pieces
1-2 medium red chili’s
3 tablespoons Sure-Jell less or no-sugar needed pectin (from a 1 and 3/4-ounce box)
3 cups sugar
1 cup apple cider vinegar
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 rosemary stems
Process:
In a food processor, pulse the cut bell pepers and jalapenos until finely chopped. Place into a pot with the vinegar and rosemary; cook over medium-high heat. Bring to a boil and cover, cook for 5 mins. Remove rosemary stem. Mix the 1/2 cup sugar with the pectin. Pour into the pot and stir until completely dissolved. Stir in the rest of the sugar until combined. Remove from heat immediately. Pour into sterilized mason jars. Don’t cover with a lid until it comes to room temperature. Refrigerate and serve with a vegan feta dip, in a BLT, or with your oatmeal ♥️

#redpeppers #appetizers #jellies #fallrecipes

also let me know how we feel about ASMR vs voiceovers- i’m trying something new and would luv ur thots 

here’s how to make it:
-2 tbsp olive oil
-1/2 medium yellow onion, diced
-2 garlic cloves, minced
-1” ginger, minced
-1 small honey nut squash, peeled, reseeded, cubed into 1” piece
-1/2 tsp five spice
-2 cups chopped kale
-1 gala apple, chopped
-1 1/2 tbsp chopped rosemary leaves 
-1 tbsp sesame oil
-juice of 1/2 lemon
-4 eggs
-salt/pepper, to taste

process:
in a skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Sauté the onions, garlic, and ginger until softened, about 5-6 mins. Add the honey nut squash and five spice; toss to coat. Add 2 tbsp water and cover for 5-10 mins until softened. Once squash is fork tender, add the kale, apples and rosemary leaves. Stir and toss until combined. Drizzle sesame oil and lemon juice with a pinch of kosher salt. Toss to combine and taste to adjust seasoning (add more salt or five spice if desired). Keep stirring until the kale is bright green and slightly softened. Create 4 divots and drop 1 egg in each one. Cover and cook for 3-4 mins until the egg whites have set. Remove from heat and serve immediately with chili oil, pomegranate seeds

the BEST dish on my menu for my pop up this week was Trinidadian Pumpkin Talkari (RECIPE BELOW) 👇🏼

If there were ONE dish from the island of Trinidad and Tobago that makes me feel like the best version of myself, it is most definitely Pumpkin Talkari, specifically my Aunt Linda’s 🧍🏽‍♀️

Each bite is salty, herbaceous, and luscious like whipped butter. So if you wanted something more than basic as$ mashed potatoes this season, this is what you make

Here’s how to make it:
- 2 lbs kabocha squash, peeled & deseeded
- 1/4 cup olive oil
- 6 cloves garlic, minced
- 1/4 cup chopped cilantro
- 1 medium yellow onion, diced
- 1 teaspoon red pepper flakes, more for higher heat tolerances
- 1 teaspoon salt, to start add more to taste
- 1 tablespoon brown sugar
Process:
1. Peel calabaza/kabocha squash. TIP: Microwave the squash for 4 minutes to soften the skin. CAREFULLY slice the squash, deseed, cut it into wedges, and cut off the skin. Dice into even 1 1/2” chunks.
2. Mince garlic, onion, and chop cilantro. Heat a heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat and add olive oil.
3. Add the pumpkin garlic, onion, and cilantro to the pot with the red pepper and salt. Toss to coat and cover. Cook for 10 minutes, stirring every 5 mins. Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook until the pumpkin is tender about 20 minutes.
4. Using the back of your spoon, mash the pumpkin until smooth with some slight chunks remaining. Add the brown sugar and add more salt if needed.
5. Garnish with fresh cilantro OR my favorite mix of tahini, Egyptian dukkah, and pomegranate seeds
6. Serve with roti and dive in!

#holidayrecipes #caribbeanfood #pumpkin #sidedishes

i pray for peace, a coming of home, and resiliency for everyone impacted by this— p@lestinians, jews, muslims, human beings alike 

here’s how to make ful medames:
* 1 pint of cherry tomatoes,
* 3-4 tbsp olive oil
* 3 cloves garlic, roughly chopped
* 1/2 tsp ground cumin
* 1 15-oz can fava beans, rinsed and drained
* ½ cup hot water
* 1 lemon,
* ½ bunch flat-leaf parsley, chopped, for garnish
* 

Process
Remove 3/4 of cherry tomatoes from pint and slice in half. Heat a skillet with 2 tbsp olive oil over medium heat and add sliced tomatoes. Sear until they soften and juices begin to release. Remove from pan. In a mortar & pestle, mash chopped garlic with pinch of kosher salt until a thick paste forms. In the same pan, heat 1 tbsp olive oil and sauté garlic paste with cumin until fragrant. Add the fava beans, water, and cover. After 5 mins, mash with a potato masher and season w/ salt/pepper to taste. Add the cooked tomato and juice of 1/2 the lemon, mash until incorporated. Add more water if needed, 2 tbsp at a time.

To garnish: chop the remaining cherry tomatoes and mix with chopped parsley,  remaining lemon juice, 1 tbsp olive oil, and salt. serve with marinated yellow onion, bread, and soft boiled eggs

Beige food autumn is my prime and mushroom gumbo is my life line (recipe below ⬇️)

if you don’t like slop, you can’t hang— i don’t make the rules. It brings a sort of comfort that can never be replaced, even by that man on hinge you’re waiting for a text back from 🤭

This vegan gumbo uses a trio of mushrooms (shittake, oyster, and enoki) for a stew full of umami like the classic seafood one 😌🫵🏽

Here’s how to make it:

1/4c oil
1/4c flour
1 cup yellow onion, diced
1/2 cup celery, diced
1/4 cup green bell pepper, diced
3 garlic cloves, minced
12 ounces mushrooms (shiitake, oyster, enoki, baby Bella, etc)
4 cups vegetable stock
2 tbsp tomato paste
2 tsp ras el hanout, optional
1 can cannellini beans 
Chopped green onion, for garnish

Process:
Melt vegan butter or oil over medium heat in a skillet and add flour. Stir consistently to make a dark roux, this will take 20-30 mins for the color to change from beige to a chocolate brown. Add half the onions/bell pepper/celery, garlic, and tomato paste; saute for 4-5 mins. Add in sliced mushrooms, ras el hanout with a pinch of salt. Toss to coat, cook for 5-6 mins until mushrooms begin to soften. Add remaining onions/peppers/celery and cook for another 5 mins. Add broth and drained beans. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until thickened. If you would like it to be thicker, stir in a mixture of 1 tbsp cornstarch to 1 tbsp water. Serve over rice, garnish with chopped green onion and crystal hot sauce.

sweet potato gochujang orzotto— because risotto is tired and so are you

i love a hack that saves me time so i can ruminate about what i said last weekend instead of stirring rice

here’s how you can to

* 2 tablespoons plant-based salted butter
* 1 shallot, minced
* 4 garlic cloves, minced
* 1 1/2 cups orzo
* 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon
* 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg
* 2 tablespoons gochujang
* 9 ounces orzo

process:

My mini New Orleans Eaters Guide is LIVE! (Recommendations Below)

New Orleans School Of Cooking (@nolaschoolofcooking) – A beautiful locally owned cooking school, teaching locals and tourists how to whip up fire Creole cuisine like Shrimp n Grits, Bananas Foster, and gumbo (OBVIOUSLY). cornbread casserole is quite literally the only thing you must make this year— with gochujang sage butter ✨♥️🫡🤝

my aunt linda’s sister recipe made this about a decade ago and it has had me in shackles since— and i hope it does for you too

here’s how to make it:
1 package of an 8-ounce Jiffy corn muffin mix
1/2 cup (1 stick) regular or plant-based salted butter
5-6 sage leaves
1 cup (8oz) regular or plant-based sour cream
1 (14.5oz) can of corn kernels, drained
1 (14.5oz) can of creamed corn
1 flax egg or whole egg
(Gochujang Sage Butter)
1 stick salted butter, softened
2 tbsp gochujang paste 
1/2 tsp cinnamon
5 sage leaves, finely chopped 

process:
Preheat oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
Melt butter in a microwave-safe dish then add sage leaves and steep for 15 minutes.

In a large bowl, mix together creamed corn, corn kernels, egg, and sour cream. Strain the melted butter into the mixture. Whisk in the Jiffy corn mix.

Pour into a greased 9x9 dish and bake for 45-50 mins until set and golden brown. Remove and chill.

Make compound butter by whisking together the softened butter with gochujang, cinnamon, and sage leaves with a hand mixer. Serve the casserole with the butter and a drizzle of honey

#cornbread #thanksgivingrecipes #sidedishes

🥕 maple harissa glazed puff pastry is my favorite way to pop off at a dinner party, and you too

This puff pastry is my favorite way to use up a bundle of carrots. Perfect for a party, excellent for yourself, will be devoured in an instant—- heres how to make it

Here’s how to make it:
- 1 lb rainbow carrots(about 8-10 medium to large carrots)
- 2 tablespoons harissa paste
- 1/4 cup maple syrup
- 3 tablespoons olive oil
- 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon & coriander
- 1/4 teaspoon cumin
- 2 rosemary stems
- 1/2 tsp salt
- 1 store-bought puff pastry
- 6oz ricotta
- 2oz goat cheese
- 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
- 1 tbsp sugar
- pinch of salt

Process
1. Preheat oven to 400F. Rinse carrots, reserve carrot stems, and slice carrots in 1/2 lengthwise. 
2. In a bowl, whisk harissa, maple syrup, olive oil, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, and salt until combined. Taste and adjust seasoning. Reserve 1/4 cup of glaze. Toss the remaining glaze w/ carrots on a sheet tray. Roast for 20 to 25 minutes.
3. While carrots roast, whip together ricotta, goat cheese, sugar, vanilla, and salt until combined. Place puff pastry on a 9x12 sheet tray. Score a 1” border around the puff pastry lightly. Generously pierce the inner section with a fork to reduce how much it puffs up. Bake for 15 mins with carrots until lightly golden. Remove and let cool
4. Spread ricotta on the puff pastry within the border. Layer carrots on top organically or in a pattern. Bake for an additional 5 mins until the crust is golden. Remove and let cool
5. In a small saucepan, add rosemary stems and reserved glaze. Stir over medium-low heat until fragrant and the glaze coats the back of a spoon. Brush onto carrots on the tart. 
6. Garnish w/ herbs or crispy carrot top stems (fried in olive oil for 30 seconds) and flaky salt.
7. Dive in

#carrots #puffpastry #appetizers #harissa

Sweet Potato-Sesame Lentil Soup with Roasted Radishes— my favorite love story 🤝

A thick luscious soup is simply better than a brothy one. I want my soup to feel like it can keep my mouth SHUT (it needs to be)

This one uses two kinds of sesame notes: tahini and toasted sesame oil that simply feels like a hug. 

Here’s how to make it:
2 large sweet potatoes
2 tbsp olive oil
1 yellow onion
4 garlic cloves
1/2 tsp cumin
1 tsp coriander
1 cup lentils
2 cups veggie stock
4 cups water
1 tsp kosher salt
1/4 cup tahini
2 tbsp toasted sesame oil
3 tbsp rice vinegar
Process:
Preheat oven to 350F. Rinse potaotes, pierce with a fork 3-4 times and wrap in foil. Roast for 45 minutes until tender. While roasting, dice your onion and mince your garlic. Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a pot over medium hear. Saute onions for 4-5 mins. Add garlic and saute for 2 mins. Add the cumin, coriander, and tomato paste. Saute until fragrant. Rinse your lentils and add to the pot. Toss to coat and then cover with 2 cups broth and kosher salt. Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook for 10 minutes. Uncover, stir, and add 2 more cups of water. Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook again for 10 mins. Remove sweet potatoes, let cool, and remove the skin. Add to the pot and stir into the lentils. Add another 2 cups water. Stir until incorporated. Stir in the tahini, sesame oil, and rice vinegar. Using an immersion blender, blend until smooth. If you want a thinner consistency, add 1/2 cup water a time until the desired consistency. Add salt to taste, if needed.
Garnish with roasted radishes, green onion, and gochugaru.

#soupseason #lentils #sweetpotato #sesameoil

Poached pears with tahini cream and hazelnut crumble. #PureLeafPartner

 I love love love a no-bake dessert that comes together with few ingredients, particularly @pureleaf Sweet Iced Tea (pear)ed with cranberries and an array of spices that will jingle your bells 

Here’s how to make it:
4 ripe but firm Bosc pears
1 (18.5)fl ounces @pureleaf Sweet Tea
1/4 cup sugar
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
2 cinnamon sticks
2 star anise
4 cloves
2 cardamom pods
1 cup fresh cranberries
1 lemon

Tahini Cream
3/4 cup non-dairy milk of choice 
1/3 cup tahini
1/4 cup cornstarch, sifted
1/4c  confectioner’s sugar
1/4 tsp kosher salt
1/4 tsp almond extract

Hazelnut Oatmeal Crumble
4oz toasted hazelnuts
1/2 cup rolled oats
2 tbsp melted unsalted butter
2 tbsp dark brown sugar

Process:
-Peel the pears, keep the stems and toss with lemon juice. Heat the sweet tea, sugar, spices and cranberries in a a deep skillet over medium heat. Bring to a simmer and then gently place pears into the pan. Cover and cook for 20-30 mins, gently flipping the pears once, until fork tender.

While pears cook, make the tahini cream. Whisk together the powdered sugar and cornstarch until combined. Add 1/4 cup of the almond milk and whisk until smooth. Add the remaining  and place over medium low heat. Continue stirring until thickened, about 3-4 mins. Stir in the tahini and almond extract with a pinch of salt until smooth and incorporated. The cream should easily coat the back of a spoon.

Once pears are done. Serve with tahini cream and hazelnut crumble! 

#poachedpears #easydessert #healthydessert #pears

🫒🫦🫒 Fried Olive Cream-Cheese Bites… because you are what you eat (a snack) 

These are inspired by the iconic Trader Joe’s Fried Olive Bites, but with a Maghrebi twist- because who wouldn’t want harissa, tahini, or Moroccan spices at their holiday table? 🤲🏻

They’re super simple to make and perfect to prep (just freeze the stuffed olives sans breading & prepare to fry the day of the party which gives you time to practice throwing as$.🍑

Here’s how to make them:
* 10-12 ounce pitted, Castelvetrano Olives
* 1/2 cup panko bread crumbs, or almond meal
* 2 tbsp nutritional yeast
* 1 tbsp sumac
* 1 tsp coriander
* 2 tbsp nutritional yeast
* 1/2 tsp fine kosher salt
* 2 eggs, beaten
* neutral-high smoke point oil, for frying
{Cream Cheese Filling}
* 1/3 cup cream cheese, softened
* 2 tbsp sugar
* 1/2 tbsp sumac
* 1/2 tsp ras el hanout
* pinch of sea salt
{Harissa Maple Dipping Sauce}
* 2 tbsp vegan yogurt
* 1 tbsp tahini
* 1 tbsp maple syrup
* 1 tbsp harissa
* 1/4 tsp garlic powder
* pinch of cumin
* salt, to taste
Process
1. Add the cream cheese, ras el hanout, & sumac to a bowl. Using a hand-held blender, whip the ingredients until incorporated. Place into a piping or Ziploc bag to fill the pitted olives. Set aside.
2. Make your breadcrumb mixture by whisking together panko, nutritional yeast, sumac, & salt until combined. Beat your eggs in a separate bowl. Set aside.
3. Remove olives from the jar & pat dry.
4. Fill each olive fully with the filling using a piping bag or Ziploc bag (with a TINY hole cut from the corner).
5. Coat olive in beaten egg, then the breadcrumbs. Repeat once more. I like to freeze the olive for 15 to 20 minutes before frying.
6. Heat a small saucepan with high smoke point oil over medium heat. The oil is ready to fry when you drop a breadcrumb into the pot & it sizzles. Fry 2 to 3 olives at a time. Dry on a paper-lined plate.
7. Make the dipping sauce by blending all of the ingredients until combined. Taste & adjust seasoning to taste.
8. Serve in a cocktail glass w/ fresh sprigs of rosemary cause you’re fun & dive in!

#olives #partysnacks #traderjoesrecipes #holidayrecipes

🧍🏽Mushroom stew cause you deserve a meal as scrumptious as you are

this is a rich, cozy, silky mushroom stew that was inspired by the iconic Mushroom French Dip sandwich from @eszettla (with a little North African flair and spice)

Here’s how to make it:
Cauliflower Mash:
1 head of cauliflower
8 cups water
3 tbsp miso
1 tsp salt
2 tbsp butter
1 garlic clove, minced
2 tbsp cooking liquid 

Mushroom Stew 
8 oz mixed mushrooms
1 yellow onion
2 tbsp butter
Pinch of salt
1/2 tsp cinnamon
1/2 tsp chilli powder
1/2 tsp ginger
1 tbsp preserved lemon paste (sub w/ juice of 1 lemon
2 tbsp chopped tarragon
Slurry: 1 1/2 cup water + 2 tbsp flour

Process:
1. Remove cauliflower from stems into florets. Add to a pot of water (8 cups + miso) and bring to a boil over medium high heat. Reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook for 20-25 minutes.
2. Reserve 1/4 cup cooking liquid, then strain. Add to a food processor w/ butter, garlic, and cumin. Puree until smooth. Add cooking liquid 2 tbsp at a time if needed. Set aside
3. In a skillet, melt 2 tbsp butter over medium heat. Add onions and sautéed for 6 to 8 mins until slightly golden. Add additional 2 tbsp butter and sauté spices and garlic until fragrant. 
4. Add mushrooms w/ splash of water. Season w/ a pinch of salt, cover and cook for 5 to 7 minutes. Stir consistently.
5. Once mushrooms have cooked down, add preserved lemon paste and tarragon. Toss to coat. Pour in slurry and stir until sauce thickens and is combined. 
6. Serve over cauliflower mash w/ fresh parm and herbs.

#comfortfood #mushrooms #cauliflower #winterrecipes

Blueberry-Rosemary Thumbprint cookies that only need a few basics, @blueberries , some butter and a thumb.

I love speaking out for those who are unheard (thumbprint cookies) in a world full of the same ol’, same ol’ (chocolate chip cookies). Put some respect on blueberries during the winter. Put some respect on thumbprint cookies! Make em, eat em, share em.

Here’s how:
Blueberry-Rosemary Jam
- 1 dry pint fresh blueberries
- 1/2 cup sugar
- 1 teaspoon lemon juice
- 2 sprigs of rosemary
Thumbprint Cookies
- 1 cup unsalted butter (room temp)
- 1/3 cup sugar
- 1/3 cup brown sugar
- 1 egg yolk
- 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
- 1/2 tsp almond extract
- 2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
- 2 tsp cornstarch
- 1/2 tsp salt
- 1/2 cup chopped pecans, pistachios

Process:
Make the blueberry-rosemary jam: To a pot, add blueberries, sugar, & lemon juice; stir over med heat until the sugar dissolves and the blueberries break down. e sugar has dissolved, bring heat to low and add the rosemary sprigs. Cook for 20-30 minutes, stirring every 5-10 minutes to prevent it from browning. Once the jam has thickened, remove the rosemary stems. Remove from heat and let cool.
Make cookie dough: Preheat oven to 375F and place a rack in the center of the oven. In a large bowl, beat the softened butter using an electric mixer until creamy, about 2-3 mins. Add the sugars; mix until incorporated, about 1 minute. Add 1 egg yolk with the vanilla and almond extract. Beat once more until incorporated. In another bowl, whisk together flour, salt, and cornstarch. Gently pour 1/3 of the flour mixture at a time into the butter mixture and mix until combined. Once combined, scoop the dough using a 1 1/2” cookie scoop and roll it in between the your hands till smooth with no cracks. Gently roll balls into the chopped nuts and place on a parchment-lined plate. Using your thumb or the back of a rounded spoon, gently press into the dough to form an indent. Repeat with all of the dough. Freeze for 30 mins. Once chilled, spoon the jam into each cookie to the brim. Place on parchment lined trays, 2” apart, and bake for 11-12 minutes or until golden around the edges. Let cool on the sheet tray and serve.

#blueberries

Coffee Chocolate Tart just inherently sounds like the best kind of dessert for the chaos that is the week before the holidays

As a chocolate girlie, my mom knows that chocolate and coffee are destined lovers 👨‍❤️‍💋‍👨 The chocolate notes pair SO WELL with @Dunkin’s Holiday Blend and the hints of spice in between each sip! #DunkinPartner

Here’s how to make it:

* 1 cup brewed @Dunkin Holiday Blend coffee, cooled to room temperature
* 1 14-ounce can coconut cream, CHILLED IN FRIDGE OVERNIGHT 
* 1/2 cup chopped dark chocolate
* 1/4 cup cornstarch
* 1/4 cup maple syrup or agave syrup
* 1 teaspoon cinnamon
* 1/2 cup powdered sugar, sifted
* 1 teaspoon vanilla extract

{Make The Crust}
1. Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C)
2. Blitz cookies in a food processor until fine. Add melted butter and kosher salt. Pulse until combined. Press the mixture into the bottom and up the sides of a 9-inch tart. Bake for 8 mins and remove immediately.

{Make the Filling}
* Brew your @Dunkin Holiday Blend coffee. In a saucepan over medium heat, combine the coffee and coconut cream (scooped from the chilled can, leaving the liquid behind). Stir until well combined and heated through.
* Add the chopped chocolate and stir until smooth.
* In a bowl, whisk the cornstarch, maple syrup, and cinnamon until cornstarch is dissolved. Pour into the pot and whisk over low heat, consistently, until it thickens. Add the dark chocolate chips or chopped chocolate into the coffee and coconut cream mixture, stirring constantly until the chocolate melts and the mixture is smooth.
* Remove from heat and sift in the powdered sugar. Stir until incorporated. Then stir in the vanilla extract. Let cool. 
* Pour into the crust. Using an offset spatula, smooth the filling out. Cover with plastic wrap, ensuring it touches the surface to prevent a film from forming. Chill overnight until firm.
* Before serving, garnish with cool whip and shaved chocolate.

Creamy Gochujang Vegetable Galette for when you’re brain feels like a bumper car rink but you still need to impress

A galette is a superior savory bakery item. The stakes are low like your drive. But the reward is the boost of serotonin you needed

Here’s how to make it:
1 pie crust
6oz cream cheese, room temp
3 tbsp gochujang
1 tsp orange zest
2 tsp chopped sage, divided
1/2 tsp salt
1/4 tsp cinnamon
1 medium butternut squash, remove the “butt”
1 medium sweet potato
1 purple carrot
1 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp sesame oil
1 egg yolk

Process: Preheat oven to 375F and position rack in the middle. Bring the pie crust to room temp and make the filling. Combine the cream cheese, gochujang, orange zest, 1 tsp sage, salt, and cinnamon in a bowl until combined. Set aside. Prepare the vegetables by using only the thinner part of the squash and saving the “butt” all other butternut needs. Peel and slice into thin 1/2” slices. Peel and slice the potato into 1/2” slices. Peel the carrot and cut diagonally to arrange in the center of the galette. Roll out the pie crust on a large sheet tray to a diameter of about 12” Spread the cream cheese in the center of the pie crust, leaving about 2” of crust around the perimeter. Arrange the squash first in a circle, then the sweet potato on top, and then the carrots (sort of like rows of petals). Fold the crust around the border over and crimp it to enclose the perimeter of the veggies. Whisk the egg yolk and use a pastry brush to coat the crust. Drizzle olive oil and sesame oil on top and garnish with the remaining chopped sage and a bit of sugar. Bake for 40-50 mins or until vegetables are tender. Let cool and then serve w/ grated parmigiana reggiano.

#gochujang #galette #rootvegetables #savoryfood

Haldi Doodh Oats are probably my most requested recipe (which seems silly, but the girlies want comfort and ease)

Extra flavorful, extra luscious, and extra beneficial thanks to @gardenoflife Golden Flax Meal that’s packed full of healthy Omega-3’s (and it’s also the best egg substitute around) #GOLPartner

Here’s how to make it:
1/2 tbsp butter or coconut oil
3/4 tsp turmeric
1/2 tsp cinnamon
1/4 tsp ginger
1/4 tsp cardamom
1/2 cup rolled oats
Pinch of salt
1 cup milk of choice
1 tablespoon of @gardenoflife Golden Flax Meal
Maple syrup, to taste
Toppings of choice (yogurt, tahini, mixed berries, and banana)
Process: In a pot, melt the butter over medium heat. Once melted, add the turmeric, cinnamon, ginger, and cardamom. Bloom the spices for a minute until fragrant. Add the oats, toss to coat, and add the almond milk with a pinch of salt. Cook the oats, stirring frequently, for 3-5 minutes. Add the flax meal and maple syrup and stir to combine. Cook for another minute and plate. Garnish with toppings of choice. Dive in!

first meal of 2024 🤝 vegan sancocho 

sancocho was one of my favorite cozy meals that i begged my mom to make as a kid— it’s flavorful and salty in the best way, like you 👄

using mushrooms instead of meat makes this a bit friendlier on the planet and accessible for the vegan girlies in your life

here’s how to make it (recipe in bi0 too):
3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
6oz shiitake mushrooms
8oz baby bell mushrooms
1/4 cup sofrito
1 tbsp tomato paste
4 cups water
1 tbsp vegetable stock paste
1 green plantain
2 large carrots
12oz kabocha squash
8oz yuca root, substitute with baby potato
2 bay leaves
1/4 cup parsley
fresh chopped parlsey, for garnish
avocado, for garnish

//Process 
Prepare the veggies by quartering the mushrooms. Rinse the kabocha squash, remove the seeds, and chop the squash into 2-inch pieces. Peel the plantain, yuca, and carrots and cut them into even 1” pieces.
Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a pot over medium-low heat. Add mushrooms and saute until softened and slightly browned, about 5-6 minutes. Remove and add remaining olive oil. Add the sofrito and saute until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Add tomato paste and stir to combine. Pour in 4 cups water and stir in the vegetable stock base until incorporated. Bring to a boil.

Add the starchier vegetables that take the longest to cook first (squash and yuca) then reduce to a simmer. Cook for 10 minutes. Then add the remaining vegetables like carrots, potato, and mushrooms. Toss in the 2 bay leaves, cover, and cook for 15-20 minutes until vegetables are fork tender. Add more water, 1 cup at a time, if needed.

Stir and taste, adding more salt and/or pepper if needed. Stir in the chopped parsley and serve. Garnish with sliced avocado, fresh parsley, and cracked black pepper.

#sancocho #puertoricanfood #stews #soupseason #rootvegetables

put some RESPECT on pound cake, specifically this Cranberry-five spice pound cake 🤧💖 (recipe below)

It’s the perfect vessel that’s consistent, can adapt, welcomes new flavors of the sun into its life- unlike your dream man. I love pairing cranberries with warm flavors like cinnamon, five spice, cardamom. I kind of look at flavors like color pairings— most of the time they just work. Give it a try and add some nutmeg to this girlie too

The full recipe is link*ed in b*io! Or below! 

* 1lb salted butter softened, room temperature
* 1 ¾ cups white sugar
* 6 large eggs, room temp
* 1 tsp vanilla extract
* 1 tsp almond extract
* ½ cup unsweetened black tea, brewed double-strength
* 3c all-purpose flour, sifted
* ½ tsp sea salt
* 2 tsp five spice
1. Set a rack in the center of your oven and preheat oven to 350F. Grease a 9” bundt cake pan then dust it with flour. Set aside.
2. In a large bowl, using a hand or stand mixer, cream butter until fluffy and lighter in color, about 3 minutes. Add sugar and continue mixing until combined and fluffy. Mix in the eggs, one egg at a time, ensuring each one is incorporated into the batter before adding the next one.  Lastly, add the brewed tea and extracts and mix until incorporated. 
3. In a separate bowl, whisk together flour and salt. Fold the flour into batter in 3 batches. Set aside. In a small bowl, toss the cranberries with 1 tablespoon of all-purpose flour until coated.
4. Spoon 1/3 of the batter into the pan. Evenly press a handful of cranberries into the batter, then dust with some five spice. Spoon another 1/3 of the batter on top, repeating this process until you reach the edge of the bundt pan. Place in the center rack of the oven and bake for about 1 hour or until golden and a clean toothpick comes out when pressed into the center of the cake.
5. Let cool in the bundt pan for 10 minutes, then invert it and remove from the pan to finish cooling on the counter.
6. Dive

“Caramelized” Leek, Ginger, Egg Galettes— for your 3am feast after hooman activity (recipe below) 🍼✨♥️

I’ve recently switched over from miso to doenchang— Korea’s fermented soybean paste that’s very similar in texture and taste to miso. And when you add a spoonful to leeks that you want to caremlize but don’t have the patience for, you have a cheaters way to a similar umami and color minus the hour wait

Here’s how to assemble!
-4 leeks
-2 tbsp olive oil
-1 tbsp doenchang 
-pinch of salt
-1 pie crust, room temp
-4 tbsp ginger jam
-5 eggs
-everything but the bagel seasoning

Process:
1. Preheat oven to 400F. Remove the leek greens from the stems and slice the stems in 1/2. Rinse the leeks in a bowl of cold water to remove any dirt. Once clean, cut into thin strips horizontally.
2. In a skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the doenchang and leeks with a pinch of salt. Stir until incorporated. Keep stirring for 10-12 minutes until slightly golden and cooked down. Remove from pan.
3. Roll out a pie crust and take a large bowl (about 6-8 inches in diameter) and press into the dough, to create our mini galettes. Repeat with the remaining dough after rolling it out to the same thickness again. 
4. Spoon a tablespoon of ginger jam in the center. Add the leeks around the perimeter, leaving about 1” on all sides to fold over. Lay the leeks to create a little border for the egg to sit into once these bake. Fold the pie crust around the edge and crimp it so it covers some of the leeks. 
5. Whisk one egg and lightly brush the exposed pie crust edges with it. Top the crust with everything but the bagel seasoning. Bake for 20-25 minutes or until the edges are golden. Remove from oven and crack 1 egg, gently, into each center. Bake for another 5-6 mins.
6. Let cool, remove from pan and g arnish with hot sauce, herbs, or store in the fridge as a snack for later.

#galette #leeks #breakfastideas

Gnocchi is a pillow princess, like gochujang alla vodka is iconic (recipe below) 👸🍝

As someone who’s okay to pass on Italian food 90% of the time, this is my favorite way to elevate the traditional Roman dish with some flair from gochujang and spices like cinnamon and nutmeg. Here’s how:
2 ounces shiitake mushrooms, minced
2 garlic cloves, minced
1 shallot, minced
2 tbsp olive oil
1/4 cup vodka
3 tbsp gochujang paste
1 tbsp tomato paste
1/4 tsp cinnamon
1/4 tsp nutmeg
2 tbsp cream cheese, substitute with vegan alternative of choice if needed
3/4 cup milk of choice, substitute with vegan alternative of choice if needed
16 ounces gnocchi
salt/pepper, to taste
Chopped green onion, for garnish
parmigiano reggiano, for garnish
black sesame seeds, for garnish

1. Mincing your shiitake mushrooms, garlic cloves, and shallot. Heat a skillet over medium heat. Add the mushrooms (without the oil) and saute for 5-6 minutes until slighlty browned. Drizzle olive oil over the mushrooms and add the minced shallots and garlic. Saute for 1-2 minutes. 
2. Gently pour in the vodka and cook down for about 1 minute, the liquid should reduce by 1/2. Add the gochujang paste, tomato paste, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Stir until combined and slightly dissolved. Stir in the milk and cream cheese until incorporated. The sauce should be silky and smooth with bits of the mushroom peeping through. 
3. Cook the gnocchi and/or pasta of choice. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the cooked gnocchi to the sauce in the pan. It’s okay if some of the cooking liquid is transferred over as the starch in that liquid will help emulsify and thicken the sauce.
4. Toss the gnocchi in the sauce until combined. Season with salt/pepper, to taste. Once coated, plate the gnocchi. Garnish with chopped green onion, freshly grated parmigiano reggiano, and a sprinkle of black sesame seeds
5. Dive in!

#gnocchi #gochujang #easydinnerideas #pastalovers
